content.2:
Subject: Ethnic Day
Text: Hi everyone!

We, the Cultural Committee, are looking to conduct an annual Ethnic Day in
our institute. For this event, we will have all in campus (profs, students,
staff, everyone) dressed in formal attire. We would like to know from you
the answer to a couple of questions.

Q1: Which day would you prefer the Ethnic Day to happen?
a) Wednesday, 4th September 2019
b) Thursday, 5th September 2019

Q2: Would you be willing to get dressed up in your ethnic attire should you
have an 8:30am class?
a) Yes
b) No

Please fill out the following form to answer these questions. Your answers
will help us in making the choice.
Form:
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdGE5FieCP3tVvPI3VfQyw-5IN8FXc-29lutvY5EM2YJwmG2Q/viewform?usp=sf_link

Thanks and Regards
Mehul Bose
General Secretary, Cultural Affairs
IIT Dharwad

content.5:
Subject: Ethnic Day @ IIT Dharwad
Text: Hi Everyone!

At long last! We are proud to announce the first ethnic day of our
institute, on 5th September 2019!
As we come together to celebrate the enormous diversity which exists in our
great country, we would request everyone to wear traditional (ethnic!)
dresses. This goes for all in the institute, and no one is spared from this
request.
We would also request that you wear these dresses for as long as you can
(without breaking rules i.e. lab rules etc.), that is, from morning to
evening.
Needless to say, your attire should be sober and not attract attention for
the wrong reasons!
Hope to see a great spectacle!

Thanks and Regards,
Mehul Bose
General Secretary, Cultural Affairs
IIT Dharwad

content.7:
Subject: CHANGE150 Workshop
Text: Hi everyone,

We are proud to announce a CHANGE150 workshop in the event of the
(upcoming) 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi!

During this workshop, each participant (hopefully you!) will be handed out
a *simple postcard* and will be asked to articulate one civic change which
they passionately want to see and become. You can *draw, paint, write, or
use any handcrafted medium* to articulate your social change idea. You can
use *any language* for the same.

The details for the workshop is as follows:
Date: 26th August 2019
Time: 9:00pm
Venue: Room No. 23

"Be the change you want to see in this world" - Mahatma Gandhi

Thanks and Regards,
Mehul Bose
General Secretary, Cultural Affairs
IIT Dharwad

content.9:
Subject: Attention: Regarding Lab Instruments
Text: Dear Students,

It has been noticed tonight, *someone tried to open the Deep freezer
forcefully (-80 C, kept outside the chemistry lab) when it was locked and
because of that the door of the freezer was not sealed properly *which has
raised the temperature from -80C to -60C in just 20-25 minutes. Further, It
took another 15-20 minutes to sort out the problem i.e. neither the door
was in a position to close nor the key was moving to unlock and the
generated gap was filled with solid ice.

*In this freezer, valuable biological samples are kept, which are used for
research purposes and those samples need the constant -80C temperature.*

Therefore, I request you all *"Please do not try to open the freezer"*.

Thanks to Souradip and the security person near the lab area for helping me.


Sincerely,
Pranjal Kumar
PhD Student (BSBE)
IIT Dharwad

content.13:
Subject: Prof. Tembe is our Dean (Student Welfare)
Text: Dear All,

This is to inform you that, I have handed over charge of Dean (Student
Welfare) to Prof. B. L. Tembe little while ago.

At the outset, I thank Prof. Seshu (Director) for giving me the opportunity
to serve as Dean (Student Welfare) and giving me the freedom, guidance and
support during my tenure.  His monumental support and confidence reposed in
me gave me enthusiasm to overcome all the challenges posed in the initial
days of getting the hostels, mess ready.

I sincerely thank Prof. Nagesh Iyer (Dean IPS), Prof. Prasanna (Dean R&D
and Faculty Welfare) for their support in the thick and thin of my tenure.


I sincerely thank all our faculty (especially wardens, mess wardens).  Their
support has made us overcome all the problems and execute things in time. I
still remember, Prof. Amlan, Prof. Rajeshwara Rao was so much involved in
purchasing all the equipment required for the mess.  Prof. Amlan and Prof.
Koushik Saha saw us through the difficulties of handling of mess for the
year 2018-2019.  I thank all the wardens who were religiously involved in
handling all the issues of students in the nascent stage.  Sometimes, I
used to wonder am I worthy enough to execute all this. I salute all the
wardens for their faith in the system and their complete surrender to the
deliverance of perfect wardenship. They never deterred from the problems
which we were facing.  They made all insurmountable tasks into simple ones
and executed them with ease.  I personally thank Prof. Gopal and Prof.
Nilkamal who have taken up the present mess wardenship. They are doing a
wonderful job and I have complete confidence that they will take care of
our messes properly.  Nothing can be achieved without enthusiasm.  I think
the sheer enthusiasm of our faculty will instill confidence in our students
about our hostel operating systems.

I sincerely thank Mr. Nagaraja (earlier OSD), Nageshrao (OSD), Assistant
Registrars (Mr. Sandeep, Mr. Anil Dhankar, Mr. Anupam) and all office staff
for their support in taking care of all hostels, messes and students. My
sincere thanks to Mr. Anupam Joshi who was keen in getting all the services
(ambulance, mess, etc) in time and making sure that they provide better
services.  My sincere thanks to Mr. Anil Dhankar and Ms. Swetha for getting
all the infrastructure to the hostels in time.

My sincere thanks to Mr. Bhendigeri who is our caretaker of Keeravani
hostel. Without his support, it is next to impossible to take care of the
concerns of all first year students.  My sincere thanks to Mr. Ravi
Ghalimath and Ms. Sujatha for their support in the allocation of hostel
rooms, getting the infrastructure in place in the hostels.  My sincere
thanks to all the staff (Mr. Gurusiddappa, Mr. Vinod Kulkarni, Mr. Anand,
Mr. Giridhar, Mr. Chidanand, Ms. Ashwini, Ms. Farheen, Mr. Shrikant, Mr.
Sambaji) for helping in the deliverance of service to students.



Last but not least, I sincerely thank all students, hostel secretaries who
made this journey possible and memorable. Students have been extremely
helpful in making our hostels better places to stay.  It is their
suggestions which have paved way to the improvement of the operation of our
hostels and messes.   My sincere apologies to those whom I have missed out
in thanking anyone for their contributions.

 I am sure, you all will continue your support to Prof. Tembe in delivering
his duties and responsibilities as Dean (Student Welfare).



 Yours sincerely,

Prabhu


My failures have been errors in judgement, not of intent (ULYSSES S. GRANT)

It takes all the running you can do, to keep in the same place (Alice in
Wonderland))

Not everything that can be counted counts

Not everything that counts can be counted (Albert Einstein)

Subject: Fwd: Self Awareness and Higher Goals in Education (SAHGE) 2019
Text: ---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Self Awareness Higher Goals in Education <sahge2019@gmail.com>
Date: Mon, 18 Mar 2019 at 3:15 PM
Subject: Self Awareness and Higher Goals in Education (SAHGE) 2019

Dear colleague,

Indian Institute of Technology, Dharwad
[image: header]


*Greetings from all of us at the OSS!*

Join us for *Fun with Solid Works*, a beginner Solid Works workshop. Get
ready with your 1050Ti GPUs on *March 17th, 2100 hrs* (just kidding, a
Pentium 4 CPU should be enough xP) in *Room No. 23*.

Designing is one of the integral part of the production process. Learning a
CAD software is, thus, essential in this digital age. The 2 hour workshop

for CAD by Dassault and by the end of it you can expect to have made a
fascinating model. Know more and register using the link below.

content.37:
Subject: Inaugural lecture on CFD by Dr. Mudkavi (Head, CSIR-4PI, Bangalore)
Text: Dear All,

We are organizing a workshop on Computational Fluid Dynamics
(a 5 days event) starting Monday, 11th June 2018. You are invited
for the inaguration scheduled at 9.50am tomorrow.

The inaugural lecture on Computational Fluid Dynamics by
Dr. Vidyadhar Mudkavi (Head, CSIR, 4PI) has been arranged as
follows:

Day and Date: Monday, 11th June 2018
Venue: Class Room Number: 23
Time: 9.50am to 11.00am

This is followed by Q&A session during the Tea break.

Spearker Bio:
Dr. Vidyadhar Mudkavi obtained his BTech in Aeroutnautical
Engineering from IIT Kanpur in the year 1983 followed by ME in Aerospace
Engineering from IISc, 1985 and PhD from California Institute of
Technology,
USA in the year 1991. He worked as a Scientist and later as a Head at the
Computational and Theoretical Fluid Dynamics (CTFD) division from 1992 to
2016 at CSIR-National Aerospace Laboratory. Since, 2016 he is Outstanding
Scientist and Head, CSIR-4PI, Bangalore. His research interets are Vortex
Dynamics, Aircraft Wakes, Atmospheric
Flows and High Performance Computing.

All are welcome to attend this inaugural lecture.

Thanks and regards,
Dhiraj.

------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------
Dr. Dhiraj V. Patil
Assistant Professor (Homepage
<https://sites.google.com/site/dvpmultiplefluidsatiitmandi/>)
Department of Mechanical Engineering,
Indian Institute of Technology Dharwad.
Dharwad - 580011, Karnataka, India.
M: 9418752087
O: 8362212829

Subject: Prevention of Chicken Pox on the campus
Text: Hello everyone!

Recently, there have been several cases of chickenpox on our campus.
If anyone of you has not been affected by, or has not been vaccinated
against chickenpox before, please take precautionary measures and make sure
to fill the form attached below. In case you don't remember, please confirm
with your parents. Students who are infected with the disease are also
requested to strictly follow precautionary measures owing to its highly
contagious nature.

Please see the institute doctor immediately if you notice any of the
symptoms, which include mild fever and itchy rashes, or suspect that you
have chickenpox.

All the students are requested to fill the form attached below before *3 pm
tomorrow.*


Regards

Soma Siddhartha

content.50:
Subject: Take this emotional wellness test to know how stressed you are!
Text: <http://bit.ly/IITDhStressTest>
<http://bit.ly/IITDhStressTest>

Hi There,


Student life is one of the best times in one's life. Unfortunately, it also
involves quite a few worries, and many of them start almost as soon as the
new semester starts. Don't you agree? Quizzes, internships, placements,
heartbreaks, a jam-packed timetable, fitting in that show of "Ant Man and
The Wasp" into your busy schedule, you name it.

Sometimes this may cause intense, unending anxiety in our minds and
hearts.

Man! All those tests, quizzes, exams they're such major stress-inducers no?
But all tests don't have to be that way. Coz we here for you fam.


This time, take this unique test that won't stress you but will tell you
just how stressed you are.

show me how stressed i am <http://bit.ly/IITDhStressTest>

Understanding yourself is always a challenging task. If you feel like you
have hit a roadblock, help is just a click away
<http://bit.ly/IITDhStressTestChat> :)

*Go ahead, unleash the best version of yourself!*


*Standing With You, Team YourDOST *

content.57:
Subject: Internet connectivity
Text: Dear Ashutosh

This is the update on internet connectivity as given by Prof. Rajshekhar
who is putting in lot of efforts in this regard.

Yours sincerely
Prabhu

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Rajshekar K <rajshekar.k@iitdh.ac.in>
Date: Tue, Feb 5, 2019 at 4:17 PM
Subject: Re: Lack of basic necessities in IIT Dharwad
To: Dean Student Welfare <dean.sw@iitdh.ac.in>


Dear Sir,


We are aware about the state of the Internet connectivity and are making
all possible efforts to improve it. Know that the faculty are facing
difficulties to perform their research as well. This is a problem that
affects us all.

The issue is not with the WiFi network, but instead with the Internet
connectivity of the institute itself. All premier institutions like the
IITs are to get their Internet connectivity through the National Knowledge
Network (NKN) initiative of the Government of India. Under this, we are
currently receiving a bandwidth of 100 Mbps, and are eligible for an
upgrade to 1 Gbps. We have given our request for upgradation over a year
ago. However, due to issues within NKN we are still waiting for it. We are
continually pressurizing them through different channels. The latest
promise is that the upgradation will be done in a few weeks.

We have taken a secondary connection of another 100 Mbps from BSNL. It
seems that our requirements during peak loads are higher than the available
200 Mbps.

We are also trying to add a tertiary connection of 1 Gbps. Various Internet
providers have been contacted. They have visited our premises and are
preparing their feasibility reports.

We are pursuing all available options to resolve this at the earliest

Yours sincerely
Prof Rajshekhar

>
> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> From: *Career Development Cell* <cdc@iitdh.ac.in>
> Date: Tuesday, February 5, 2019
> Subject: Lack of basic necessities in IIT Dharwad
> To: P Seshu <Director@iitdh.ac.in>, Dean Student Welfare <
> dean.sw@iitdh.ac.in>
> Cc: Students <students@iitdh.ac.in>
>
>
> Sir
> I am extremely sorry to inform you about the poor conditions of basic
> necessities in our institute.
>
> Every floor in the academic area has a water cooler machine but has anyone
> checked out of them how many actually works? Even in the Bhoopali mess
> drinking water doesn't come half of the time. Studying in an IIT, are we
> expected to go outside to buy a drinking water bottle every time we feel
> thirsty?
>
> It's been three years since our institute has established, but still we do
> not have a stable wifi connection.We are expected to do a course online via
> NPTEL and the internet facility hardly works. Even if it works then what is
> the point of getting a 75 Kbps speed (mostly) when you can't stream a video
> even in the lowest quality. We have even tried to use the internet using
> our own mobile data but the maximum speed we get during the day time is
> less than 300 Kbps. Ironically this is the four times the speed of our
> college wifi but it is still useless.
>
> I hope due attention is given to this mail and efforts will be done to
> provide the students with the basic necessities.
>
>
>
>
>
>
> --
> Professor in Mechanical Engineering, Larsen and Toubro Chair Professor,
> Dean (Academic Programme and Student Welfare)
> IIT Dharwad

content.60:
Subject: Google Explore Machine Learning Program
Text: *Hello everyone,Hope you are enjoying your holidays! This is a call for all
the ML enthusiasts for the Explore Machine Learning Program
<https://events.withgoogle.com/explore-ml-in/> presented by Google AI Team.
The deadline for submitting the applications is 15th June. We do want
maximum of you to take benefits from this opportunity  for a sponsored 2
day bootcamp by Google AI Team. Are there any queries, feel free to reach
out to explore-ml-program@google.com <explore-ml-program@google.com> or
join this Hangouts Meet <https://meet.google.com/xed-uezp-akv> on 12th
June, 5PM IST, to clear your doubts.*
*In case you know someone who fits best for this program, feel free to
share the content with them.*

[image: Explore ML Header Image]
<https://events.withgoogle.com/explore-ml-in/>

*Explore ML Bootcamp for University Students in India*

Hello Student!

We are super excited to launch the *Explore ML Program* in *India*.

Explore Machine Learning (ML) is a Google-sponsored program for university
students to get started with Machine Learning. The curriculum offers 3
tracks of Machine Learning Content (Beginner, Intermediate, Advanced) and
relies on university student facilitators to train other students on campus
to acquire that knowledge.

In order to help equip student facilitators to train others, Google is
hosting a Machine Learning Academy in Google Bangalore
<https://goo.gl/maps/QfoHrHeqfAEPuqsY6>. ML Academy is a 2-day training
experience for student facilitators to get familiar with the programs
content, meet one another and connect to Googlers.

Requirements - If you:

1. Currently are in second, third or final year of your degree
are comfortable with data structures and algorithms.
2. Have good communication and interpersonal skills.
3. Have effective listening and questioning skills.
4. Have a passion for teaching, facilitating, and/or presenting.
5. Have previous experience in working on Machine Learning (strongly
preferred).
6. Have previous teaching or facilitation experience (preferred).

If you answered yes to most of that criteria, that means that you are what
we‚Äôre looking for!

Once you accepted to Explore ML Program, you will be responsible for:

1. Attending two days facilitator training.
2. Facilitating Machine Learning workshops in your university.
3. Solving doubts and queries of the enrolled classroom students.
4. Share feedback, reports, ideas, and best practices with the programs
team at Google and other facilitators.



Last date to enroll for the program is *15th June 2019.*
[image: Image]
APPLY
<https://events.withgoogle.com/explore-ml-in/registrations/new/details/>
READ MORE <https://events.withgoogle.com/explore-ml-in/>

 Filling up this form doesn‚Äôt guarantee confirmation of acceptance in the
program.



Selected attendees would be notified by *24th June 2019*.



If you have any questions, don‚Äôt hesitate to contact us at
explore-ml-program@google.com





[image: https://ai.google/] <https://ai.google/>
Sonu Sourav
General Secretary, Technical Affairs | DSC Lead
IIT Dharwad

content.66:
Subject: Sharing an Article from NDTV on Today's Google Doodle
Text: Google Doodle Remembers Feminist Freedom Fighter Kamaladevi
ChattopadhyayKamaladevi
Chattopadhyay 115th Birth Anniversary: She was the first Indian woman to
run for a political office.




[image: Google Doodle Remembers Feminist Freedom Fighter Kamaladevi
Chattopadhyay]
NEW DELHI:  Today's Google doodle celebrates the 115th birth anniversary of
Kamaladevi Chattopadhyay, a social reformer who participated in India's
freedom struggle. Her views on women's rights issues are as relevant in the
modern times.


Born on 3 April 1903 in Mangalore, Kamladevi gradually emerged as one of
the few feminist freedom fighters the country has seen. Even after India's
independence in 1947,  she continued to work for the refugees and also
contributed to the cultural landscape. The Google doodle offers glimpses of
her body of work. Kamaladevi Chattopadhyay was a driving force behind
setting up of key cultural institutions in the country including National
School of Drama, World Crafts Council and Sangeet Natak Academy.


She lost her father at the age of seven, was married at the age of 14 and
lost her husband at the age of 16. A widow at a very young age, Kamladevi
travelled to London to study. She joined Indian National Congress in 1927
and gradually became the first Indian woman to be arrested by British for
entering Bombay Stock Exchange and sell packets of contraband salt in 1930.
In fact, Kamladevi - a rebel in her own right -  also disagreed with
Mahatama Gandhi when he opposed inclusion of women in salt satyagraha.


She was also the first Indian women to run for a political office. In 1926,
after she met the founder of All India Women's Congress, Margaret Cousins,
Kamladevi contested for a seat in Madras Legislative assembly, however, she
lost by just 55 votes.


In her memoir, she stressed on how "women had no rights" at that time. She
also pressed for Uniform Civil Code to ensure gender equality and often
voiced her opinion against child marriage. During her travels to the United
States, she befriended many American feminists to expand her worldview.



Indian author Raja Rao described the social reformer as "perhaps the most
august woman on the Indian scene today. Firmly Indian and therefore
universal, highly sophisticated both in sensibility and intelligence, she
walks with everyone, in city and country with utter simplicity."


She died on October 29, 1988.

content.70:
Subject: Approval of funds for summer projects
Text: Hello everyone,
I talked to Dean S/W for approval of emergency funds for summer projects
but he said it could be done until the annual Technical Budget is approved.
But from my side, I have arranged for funds up to 25k in which I could
allot funds to following three projects for summer. The other projects
could be done during next semester once the funds for them get approved.
The projects for which funds have been approved now are:
   Project Name                                Mentor
1. *SCARA                                        *Rohan Savakar
2. *Spyder Bot*                                  Abhinav Gupta
3.  *Dynamic Obstacle Avoidance *    Aman Singal
    * and Path Prediction*
The funds to these projects would be reimbursed in the next semester once
the Summer of Innovation '19 event is over. Reimbursement for only those
equipment would be done which would be purchased between May 1, 2019, to
July 28, 2019, and the bills should have the GST number on them. The total
amount should not exceed than that mentioned in the proposal form. Since
these are low budget projects, I hope the team could manage for the funds
themselves as of now.

I request the mentors to confirm *ASAP *that they are doing the projects
this summer so that I could freeze them and include it in the Summer of
Innovation '19 event. If they do not confirm, funds would be given to the
next low budget project.

Thanks,
Sonu Sourav
General Secretary, Technical Affairs

content.80:
Subject: Advisory for IIT Dharwad Community in view of existing & forecasted weather conditions.
Text: Dear All,



It is to inform that due to incessant rains, inclement weather conditions &
affected transport facilities; there is a limited availability of essential
commodities and daily functioning of both the messes at IIT Dharwad is
affected.



In this regard, suitable arrangements have already been made for providing
uninterrupted catering services to the students. However, the full-fledged
menu may not be served until normal conditions prevail. Also, there shall
be limited availability of essential services like power and water supply.



Considering the situation, IIT Dharwad community (especially fresh
admissions) is advised to exercise maximum caution and refrain from
venturing out of the campus. Since most of the roads leading in & out of
Dharwad city are in dangerously poor state, shops & outlets are not fully
operational and water logging is a common scenario; staying in the campus
is recommended.



Therefore, maximum support and co-operation from all at IIT Dharwad during
this period is expected. In case of any confusion or difficulty, Assistant
Registrar (Contract & Services) at IIT Dharwad may kindly be contacted
through email.

-- 
*Thanks & regards,*

*Lt Cdr Anupam Joshi*
*Assistant Registrar (C & S)*
*Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Dharwad*
*WALMI Campus, Belur Industrial Area*
*Near High Court, Dharwad, Karnataka - 580011*
*Mob: 9820783591*

Text: Dear Sir/Madam,


Greetings!

It gives me immense pleasure to inform you that the Department of  Social
Science and Humanities of the prestigious National Law University Jodhpur
is conducting two short certificate courses of two weeks duration each. The
titles of the courses are:



   - Economics of Development, and
   - Public Economics


The courses are designed with a view to imparting the basic idea of growth,
development and sustainable development to the participants. The course
content touches upon the role of the government in increasing welfare
through its policies. The Certificate Courses would be beneficial for the
students of  Law, Commerce and Arts. Participation is open to all Under
Graduate and Post Graduate students, those preparing for Civil Services,
NET and other competitive exams, scholars pursuing  PhD, or those who are
involved in independent research, social activists and professionals.

content.92:
Subject: Transparency in Election.
Text: Hello all,
         Elections were conducted for some of the important posts in
college on August 06,2018. Our college needs new secretaries but the way it
was conducted was not satisfactory. There are may things related to
election and election procedure which needed to be shared among others.
There should have been more transparency and carefulness as these elections
have some meaning.
*According to me the election was not fair.*

I have few question which should be answered:

1. Why was there no option for "None Of The Above"? If someone is not
working properly and still is the only one applying for the post, why
should (s)he be getting 100% votes?

2. Who selected the students involved in conduction of elections and on
what basis?

3. Who verified and validated the software/program they wrote for this
purpose?

4. Why was the options not in the format of multiple choice? Even if it was
in drop down menu type, why was it not in alphabetical order?

5. At the time of applying as a candidate, we were asked to give a write up
of 140 words or less.
Why was it not displayed in the voting site at the time of election?

6. Why was the candidate's photo, roll number not displayed in the voting
site which are unique to the candidate? Only names were shown which can be
almost similar to someone else.

7. Why was the post of mess councilor removed even after taking candidate
names for the post? That too, without informing the candidates.

8. Why was the contesting candidate names not released before the election?

9. Was anyone from academics involved in these elections?

10. When will the vote counts be released to the students?

There might be many students having these questions in their mind. I am
just an individual speaking it out.
*I request everyone reading this mail to help us get answers to these
questions. Without them, these elections are useless.*



 BTW can someone with FR/DX grade contest election?

Regards,
MD RIZWAN ANSARI
CSE160010015
IIT DHARWAD.

Computation Musicology aims to use computational tools for analysis of music.
This course will be an optional 1 credit course for this semester. It is
structured with no prerequisites needed in Signal Processing and Machine
Learning. The course instructor is  '*Dr. Ajay Srinivasamurthy*', PhD in
Music Technology, who is an applied scientist at the Amazon Alexa Machine
Learning Group in Bangalore. There willl be a short orientation talk by
Dr.Ajay Srinivasamurthy (venue and time will be notified). Please go
through the attached pdf file for more details on the course.

content.108:
Subject: Drawing Competition
Text: Hello guys and gals!
   Around the world, the art of women inspires thought and provokes action.
Being women is itself a graceful art. So, on this occasion of women's day
lets put our thoughts about women and struggles they face and the way they
perceive life on paper.
   *Fine arts club is holding a cartoon sketch *(writing with drawing
allowed) *competition *celebrating the International Women's Day .

*Deadline : Monday 1 pm.*
How to submit will be notified soon.

Until then happy drawing!
Note : Winners will have a chance to participate in CultRang at IIT Goa

Men and Women have different roles, but have equal rights.


Deeksha N,
Fine Arts Secretary
content.109:

We are pleased to announce the results of the Photography Competition
conducted on Independence Day. Based on their compositions, the photos were
divided into 2 categories, each judged separately: Independence Day theme

uploaded to our college website.

request them to meet our Physical Instructor, Ravi sir.

Hi

Greetings from TITAN COMPANY LTD....!

Here is a chance to win 2 Lakh worth prizes at "Hackathon'18"

*HACKATHON‚Äô18 ‚Äì MICRO MOTOR USE CASES DEVELOPMENT*


*THE TASK IN HAND*

Titan is aiming to make a significant impact on the lives of their
customers (includes business entities) by creating devices in the personal
accessories space (wrist, bags, wallets, belts and eyewear) that would help
them simplify a part of their daily activities/ daily industrial
requirements. The task is to first identify the problems/ personal use
cases/ business use cases and then find specific solutions that can be
embedded in the personal accessories or any other products for any kind of
an industry. The problem should address a large base and the solution needs
to be scalable.

*PARTICIPANTS*

*All IITs & Anna University*

The event is open to all *students, faculty members, research scholars,
project associates* attached to the above universities

*EXPLAINING THE PRODUCT/ CHALLENGE*

Titan will make an exclusive session for registered participants by
demonstrating the micromotor product and its technical details

*REWARD*

‚Ä¢       Total prize money worth  Rs 2.0 lakhs

‚Ä¢       Internship offers from TITAN

‚Ä¢       Support up to Rs.5000/- for finalists for proto development

‚Ä¢       Titan will supply sample micro motor for finalists based on the
applications submitted by them

Mentorship by the Titan team to refine the POCs and proto developments for
the selected projects


Follow this link for the website <https://titan-hackathon.com/>, and this
link for registration <https://goo.gl/forms/PHXsDPm2bSrkxkX32>.

content.132:
Subject: A Talk by Professor Hendrik Van Maldeghem
Text: Dear All,
We have a distinguished speaker Professor Hendrik Van Maldeghem who would
give a colloquium talk on Wednesday 16th January, 2019. The talk is aimed
for the undergraduate audience. I will announce the time and place in a
follow-up mail.
Please find below a short sketch of Professor Maldeghem's contributions.
Amlan

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
About the speaker
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Professor Dr. Hendrik Van Maldeghem is a very distinguished contemporary
geometer with many major contributions to the theory of incidence
geometries and the geometries of algebraic groups ( technically called
 buildings). Through his own research contributions (more than 250 major
publications), monographs  and his phd students  over the last few decades,
he, along with Professor Joseph Thas, has been the driving force in
building the University of Ghent as one of the major centres of the world
 for incidence geometries. He is also a recipient of many national and
international academic honors.

content.136:
Subject: Remembering Girish Karnad
Text: Dear All,

Our non-stop news feeds might have informed many of us that the great
playwright and actor Girish Karnad passed away today.

What many of us may not know is Karnad's childhood connect and fondness for
the city of Dharwad- where he studied and grew up.

Sharing with you a candid documentary on him, where Karnad  gives us a walk
through Dharwad and his memories of it. Of course the film also documents
Karnad's journey to Oxford and beyond.

Do watch if you find some time:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TAQhtAc0SuQ
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TAQhtAc0SuQ>



Warmly,
Ridhima

content.142:
Subject: Talk by Prof. Girish Chowdhary, UIUC on Oct 22, 2018
Text: Dear all,

All are cordially invited to attend the following talk, which will be over
Skype.

Title:  The Robots are Coming ‚Äì to your Farm!
(AKA: Autonomous and Intelligent Robots in Unstructured Field
Environments)

Speaker: Prof. Girish Chowdhary, Assistant Professor, UIUC
Date: October 22, 2018 (Monday)

Time: 4:00 pm

Venue: Classroom No. 115

Abstract:
What if a team of collaborative autonomous robots grew your food for you?
In this talk, I will demonstrate some key technological advances that are
bringing this future a lot nearer! Equipment manufacturers have been
automating large agricultural equipment ‚Äì tractors, harvesters, and even
excavators; but automating large equipment only addresses a part of the
agricultural labor crisis. Large equipment cannot be used in wet, muddy,
and uneven fields; it cannot be used when the crop canopy grows; and it is
expensive. Furthermore, practices like blanket spraying, tilling, and the
increasing size of equipment are leading to critical sustainability
problems: Herbicide resistant weeds, soil compaction, increasing carbon
footprints, and pesticide runoff are just a few of these problems. The
focus of this talk is on the new breed of lightweight, compact, and highly
autonomous field robots that my group is creating and deploying in fields
across the US: TerraSentia. I will also discuss new algorithms for robust
long-duration autonomy in harsh, changing, and uncertain
environments, including deep learning for robot embedded vision, deep
adversarial reinforcement learning for large state-action spaces, and
transfer learning for deep reinforcement learning domains..


Speaker Bio:
Girish Chowdhary is an assistant professor at the University of Illinois
at Urbana-Champaign with the Coordinated Science Laboratory, and the
director of the Distributed Autonomous Systems laboratory at UIUC. At
UIUC, Girish is affiliated with Agricultural and Biological Engineering,
Aerospace Engineering, Computer Science, and Electrical Engineering. He
holds a PhD (2010) from Georgia Institute of Technology in Aerospace
Engineering. He was a postdoc at the Laboratory for Information and
Decision Systems (LIDS) of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology
(2011-2013), and an assistant professor at Oklahoma State University‚Äôs
Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering department (2013-2016). He also
worked with the German Aerospace Center's (DLR's) Institute of Flight
Systems for around three years (2003-2006). Girish's ongoing research
interest is in theoretical insights and practical algorithms for adaptive
autonomy, with a particular focus on field-robotics. He has authored over
90 peer reviewed publications in various areas of adaptive control,
robotics, and autonomy. On the practical side, Girish has led the
development and flight-testing of over 10 research UAS platform. UAS
autopilots based on Girish‚Äôs work have been designed and flight-tested on
six UASs, including by independent international institutions. Girish is
an investigator on NSF, AFOSR, NASA, ARPA-E, and DOE grants. He is the
winner of the Air Force Young Investigator Award, the Aerospace Guidance
and Controls Systems Committee Dave Ward Memorial award, and several best
paper awards. He is the co-founder of EarthSense Inc., working to make
ultralight agricultural robotics a reality.

--
Regards,
Naveen

Greetings Everyone!

*Aparoksha* is the annual techno-management fest of *IIIT Allahabad* (a
centre of excellence in Information Technology, established by Ministry of
HRD, Govt. of India).

Aparoksha collaborates tech enthusiasts to code, design and build
innovative solutions to transform India into a digitally empowered society.

Garnering participation from reputed institutions all across the Nation and
abroad, Aparoksha boasts of highly prestigious and recognized events which
include:

*Hack In the North: *The largest student-held Hackathon of India

*CODERED: *Flagship team coding contest

*GrayHound: *The premier Biztech Quiz

*Nova: *Online Design Contest

*B00t2root: *The flagship CTF event of Aparoksha

*Confab: *Open Panel Discussion on burning issues related to the generation

*FragFest: *All India Gaming Competition

*Humblefool Cup: *Topcoder based coding contest in the profound memory of
Harsha Suryanarayana, the best acclaimed coder India has ever produced

*Alkhwarizm: *Premier Algorithmic Match among the top coders of the world

*Diversity Events: SheHacks*, the all girls hackathon & *CodeQueen*, the
all girls coding competition

To give a kickstart to the 2019's edition of Aparoksha, We take immense
pleasure in inviting you to the preliminary round of *CODERED* and
*CODEQUEEN* - two of the highly celebrated coding contests to be held in
Aparoksha‚Äò19.


Taking technoholix to a grander scale every year, *CODERED*, the flagship
competitive coding event of Aparoksha‚Äò19 is back in association with
CodeChef, larger and much better than ever. It's time to hone your
programming skills and take home the respect and exciting *prizes
worth Rs* *1,25,000
including 50,000 cash.*


CodeRed is a team event comprising a maximum of 3 members. So get ready,
team up and register on the link below-

*Link - https://www.codechef.com/CORD2019
<https://www.codechef.com/CORD2019>*
Follow CodeRed on Facebook for all the updates!

The preliminary round will be held on *CodeChef *on *March 2, 2019 *from *9:00
PM to 1:30 AM. *The *final* *round* will be held *onsite* at *IIITA* during
*Aparoksha. *The problem set for the preliminary round will comprise* 7
problems* of varying difficulty.

*CodeQueen*, in alliance with *CodeChef*, is the premier *all-girls
competitive coding contest *organized with the aim of boosting the female
technocrats and recognising their knack for coding. Team of *maximum 2
members*, CodeQueen is to be held during the Aparoksha. Push your limits
and rule the systems with your code.

The online preliminary round is scheduled on *4th March, 2019* on *CodeChef
from 9:30 PM to 12 Midnight.*

Register your teams on the link below -
*Link - https://www.codechef.com/COEN2019
<https://www.codechef.com/COEN2019>*

And code your way to amazing *prizes worth INR 14K! *
Be there to code and take back a joyous bundle of memories.

With best regards,
*O n behalf of Team Aparoksha'19  *

The Indian National Academy of Engineering (INAE) was founded in 1987 with
the aim of promoting and advancing the practice of engineering and
technology in India. The INAE Youth Conclave aims at facilitating the
engagement of Indian youth in engineering activities at the national level.
The purpose of the conclave is to encourage budding engineers to share
their ideas, to act as a platform to showcase their innovations and
ultimately to help in incubating ideas for various startups founded by the
aforementioned engineers.

The themes this year include ‚ÄúHealth is Wealth‚Äù, ‚ÄúDigital Revolution‚Äù,
‚ÄúEnvironment Protection‚Äù, ‚ÄúLab to Market‚Äù and ‚ÄúWaste to Wealth‚Äù, all of
which highlight our commitment to promoting the practice of engineering and
technology in India and sending the products made by engineers to the
market.

The schedule for the Conclave is given below.
Submission deadline: 10th July 2019
Publishing the list of shortlisted participants: 25th July 2019
Event: 9th-10th, August 2019, Venue: LHC, IIT Delhi

Mark the dates. 9th and 10th of August. And prepare to be astonished by the
various innovative ideas and products presented by India‚Äôs best and
brightest young engineers. We hope to see you there.

posting it appropriate places .

content.151:
Subject: Talk by Dr. Abhijin Adiga on 8th October
Text: Dear students and colleagues,

A talk is scheduled on 8th October (Monday) from 2 pm to 3 pm. Please find
the details below. All interested are welcome. @CSE (2nd and 3rd year)
students: please do come for the talk.

If you are interested to attend the talk, please submit this
one-question-form
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfGsqFnw0U5OOMYBZctJizWsoikTCcJPxkJTIYjrwSPcRtC9g/viewform?usp=sf_link>
.

*Title*: How to stop an epidemic? Networked dynamical systems, games and
near-optimal algorithms

*Who*: Dr. Abhijin Adiga, Research Assistant Professor, Biocomplexity
Institute of Virginia Tech

*When*: 2 pm to 3 pm, 8th October

*Where*: To be declared

*Abstract*: Many real-world phenomena such as disease/malware/rumor spread
are
modeled as propagation models on networks (e.g., SIR models).
The first part of this talk will provide an overview of such models,
associated computational problems and methodological challenges. The
second part will focus on problems pertaining to control of such processes.
For example, given a social contact network: Who should be vaccinated to
contain the spread of the virus? Which connections should be cut to prevent
the spread of malware? I will present centralized (approximation
algorithms) and decentralized (game theoretic formulations) solutions to
such questions. Our approach relies on the characterization of these models
in terms of the spectral radius of the network.

*Bio*: Dr. Abhijin Adiga is a Research Assistant Professor at the Network
Dynamics and Simulation Science Laboratory (NDSSL), Biocomplexity Institute
of Virginia Tech. Previously, he held positions as Senior Research
Associate and Postdoctoral Associate at the same department. He received
his PhD degree from the Department of Computer Science & Automation, Indian
Institute of Science in 2011. His interests are in computational modeling,
network science, algorithms, combinatorics and game theory. His current
research focuses on the foundations of dynamical processes over networks
and design & implementation of simulation systems to study invasive species
spread, infectious diseases and socio-technical systems. He is the
principal investigator on a USAID funded project on modeling invasive
species spread. His paper in AAAI‚Äô13 received ‚ÄúHonorable Mention For
Outstanding Novelty of Research Question‚Äù award.

Thanks and Regards,
Sandeep
-- 
Sandeep R. B.
Assistant Professor
Computer Science and Engineering
IIT Dharwad

content.162:
Subject: Fwd: ET Campus Stars 2018-19 | Registrations Open
Text: ---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: <c-roopashree.sharma@timesinternet.in>
Date: Fri, Sep 14, 2018, 17:42
Subject: ET Campus Stars 2018-19 | Registrations Open
To: <pro@iitdh.ac.in>


Dear Sir/Ma'am,

Greetings from The Economic Times (Digital) team.

We are pleased to inform you that the registrations for the second edition
of ET Campus Stars (ETCS) are now open and would like to invite students
from your institute to register for India‚Äôs largest program that identifies
and rewards the brightest engineering minds in the country.

The first edition of ETCS (completed last year) attracted participation
from over 25,394 students and 2,000+ engineering colleges. Of these, 33
students made it to the coveted list of ‚ÄòCampus Stars‚Äô and were felicitated
by The Economic Times.

*About ET Campus Stars 2018-19*
The program, launched in partnership with Aspiring Minds (Assessment
Partner) and Bennett University (Knowledge Partner), is open to
participation from engineering students who are in the third or final year
of an engineering course from any of the AICTE approved colleges. ETCS
2018-19 consists of four phases:

   - Phase 1: Registration and online psychometric test
   - Phase 2: Online test to assess functional knowledge
   - Phase 3: On-ground assessment of group dynamics and leadership
   - Phase 4: One-on-one interaction with Program Jury

Each phase would be followed by a shortlisting process.The students who
move to Phase 4 will be interviewed by one of the CEOs on the program‚Äôs
Jury Panel. To know more about the Program phases, Process and Jury Panel,
please visit www.etcampusstars.com.

*Why participate in ETCS?*
ETCS is not only the largest but also the most intensive program to
identify the best engineering talent. Acknowledged as a ‚Äòlife-changing‚Äô
experience by the last year‚Äôs participants, ETCS offers the following
gratifications to students:

   - Self-discovery of core strengths/ limitations on a globally-validated
   and industry-endorsed process
   - Opportunity to benchmark oneself against other engineering students
   across the country
   - Inspiring and enriching exclusive interaction with CEOs- once in a
   life-time opportunity!
   - A chance to be featured in The Economic Times and gain nation-wide
   recognition
   - Opportunity to jump-start the career early-on


*How to participate?*
To participate, students of third and final year engineering have to
register on www.etcampusstars.com and complete the online test (Phase 1) *on
or before 26 October 2018*. They can also engage with ET Campus Stars
community on Facebook www.facebook.com/ETCampusStar and Twitter
www.twitter.com/ETCampusStars

We request you to share this email with the students of your esteemed
college and encourage them to participate in the program which will prove
to be a milestone in their academic journey.

We have dispatched the hard copy of the program announcement poster to your
college address which you would receive shortly. We would need your support
in getting the poster up on the college announcement board for the students.

Looking forward to an enthusiastic response from your institute. Please
feel free to reach out to us in case of any query.

Regards,
Roopashree Sharma

anyone tonight, and we'll do our level best to ensure this doesn't happen
again.
We hope you guys accept the apology and we hope that it doesn't escalate
any further than this, because such an escalation may lead to the end of
cultural events in the college, not just for this year, but for the rest of
our college lives.
As mentioned above, I will personally make sure such an offensive incident
does not occur again and we hope you forgive us for the same.

Thanks,
Mehul Bose
General Cultural Secretary
content.164:
Subject: Talk by Prof. Girish Chowdhary, UIUC on Oct 23, 2018
Text: Dear all,

All are cordially invited to attend the following talk, which will be over
Skype.

Title: Adapt to Learn: An Adaptive Control view of Reinforcement Learning

Speaker: Prof. Girish Chowdhary, Assistant Professor, UIUC

Date: October 23, 2018 (Tuesday)

Time: 4:00 pm

Venue: Classroom No. 115

Abstract:
Adaptive control has long been the staple for control engineers when
models are poor or expensive-to-obtain. More recently, reinforcement
learning has been gaining popularity in solving problems that are
typically difficult to solve through traditional control techniques. RL
algorithms promise to learn joint perception-planning-control policies
directly from data. However, despite their successes, RL algorithms still
cannot guarantee safety and stability for engineered systems, and haven‚Äôt
yet replicated the ability of animals to transfer knowledge between
progressively harder tasks. In this talk, I will sketch my group‚Äôs pursuit
towards developing learning-based controllers for autonomous systems.
Starting from model reference adaptive control with concurrent learning
and Gaussian Processes (GPs), I will outline our journey to reinforcement
learning with GP Q-learning. I will then discuss our recent work on
adversarial deep reinforcement learning, and finally arrive at a
reimagining of reinforcement learning from the perspective of adaptation
for policy transfer.


Speaker Bio:
Girish Chowdhary is an assistant professor at the University of Illinois
at Urbana-Champaign with the Coordinated Science Laboratory, and the
director of the Distributed Autonomous Systems laboratory at UIUC. At
UIUC, Girish is affiliated with Agricultural and Biological Engineering,
Aerospace Engineering, Computer Science, and Electrical Engineering. He
holds a PhD (2010) from Georgia Institute of Technology in Aerospace
Engineering. He was a postdoc at the Laboratory for Information and
Decision Systems (LIDS) of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology
(2011-2013), and an assistant professor at Oklahoma State University‚Äôs
Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering department (2013-2016). He also
worked with the German Aerospace Center's (DLR's) Institute of Flight
Systems for around three years (2003-2006). Girish's ongoing research
interest is in theoretical insights and practical algorithms for adaptive
autonomy, with a particular focus on field-robotics. He has authored over
90 peer reviewed publications in various areas of adaptive control,
robotics, and autonomy. On the practical side, Girish has led the
development and flight-testing of over 10 research UAS platform. UAS
autopilots based on Girish‚Äôs work have been designed and flight-tested on
six UASs, including by independent international institutions. Girish is
an investigator on NSF, AFOSR, NASA, ARPA-E, and DOE grants. He is the
winner of the Air Force Young Investigator Award, the Aerospace Guidance
and Controls Systems Committee Dave Ward Memorial award, and several best
paper awards. He is the co-founder of EarthSense Inc., working to make
ultralight outdoor robotics a reality.
--
Regards,
Naveen

Subject: Invitation for SPHINX 2.0: The Annual Technical Festival of MNIT Jaipur
Text: Following the success of our biggest tech-fest SPHINX‚Äô18, we take the
opportunity to proudly invite you to its revamped edition, SPHINX 2.0, the
Annual Technical Festival of Malaviya National of Technology, Jaipur, which
will be held in the campus, commencing from 27th to 29th September 2018.
The fest is a unique confluence of technical events and extravagant
cultural activities.

This festival marks a 3-day long convergence of brilliant technological
events like Hackathons, ROBOTICS Events, Core Engineering Events, Labyrinth
(Gaming Competition). Apart from department specific topics, there are
miscellaneous topics with attractive prizes and certification to be awarded
as well. Some of the main proceedings of the fest are Technical Workshops
on Machine Learning, IoT, Ethical Hacking, Robotics, Digital Marketing,
Industrial Automation, Aerodynamics, etc. and at last to release
participants from the stress of competitions, PRONITES which includes Neon
Party Night and Celeb Night. The fest will play host to a technical
community that will comprise of young technocrats from distinguished
technical institutes from all over the country. We will be having a guest
speaker for our event TechTalks, a series of talks that celebrate the power

content.167:
Subject: Made a Blunder during your Internship? Here's How to Deal With it
Text: Dear Students,

For those of you going through internship experiences, here are some great
steps to tackle tricky experiences.
Hoping this would be of help,


Warmly,
Ridhima


P.S.: Also a good read for those hoping to intern/work soon! :)




*|MC_PREVIEW_TEXT|*
<https://yourdost.com/?yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhMail&yd_campaign=BlundersAtWork&yd_term=19>
<https://yourdost.com/?yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhMail&yd_campaign=BlundersAtWork&yd_term=19>

Be it a small oversight or a major blunder ‚Äì making a mistake in an
internship can make you feel embarrassed and leave your professional
credibility hanging in the balance. We don‚Äôt do our best when we‚Äôre
stressed, so here‚Äôs what you can do to ease out of this negative situation:
*1. Don't Panic*
Take a step back and breathe. Do what it takes to let out that pent-up
steam - go for a quick walk, talk it out with a trusted colleague or reach
out to an expert for help.
*2. Confront the worst-case scenario*
Rather than struggling to avoid the negative thoughts, try dwelling on
them. Stare them in the face and approach with a steadfast resolution to
overcome them.
*3. Apologise and earn back the trust*
By holding yourself accountable, you show that you can be trusted to fix
things. Take personal accountability for restoring trust, and gradually
work towards rebuilding it with consistent great work.
*4. Use your mistake as an opportunity to learn*
Mistakes help you strengthen your character. They are a critical part of
your life and you must learn to embrace them with an open heart and open
mind.
*5. Stop beating yourself up*
Nothing is good when done in excess, especially self-criticism. Instead of
helping you reach your goals, this excessive inner criticism will end up
disrupting your health and peace of mind.
*Made a big mistake in an internship? **Release your feelings of grief and
shame with the help of our experts.*

connect to an expert now
<https://yourdost.com/chatSession/?workgroup=demo@workgroup.chat.yourdost.com&yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhMail&yd_campaign=BlundersAtWork&yd_term=19>

*PS. If you have any questions for us, please drop us a mail at
campus@yourdost.com <campus@yourdost.com>*

Standing with You,
*Team YourDOST*


-- 


Ridhima Tewari
Assistant Professor (English)
Department of Humanities and Social Sciences
Indian Institute of Technology Dharwad
Dharwad- 580011

content.188:
Subject: Students Leave Request Procedure
Text: Dear All,

We now have a student leave request system in place. It is part of the
"court" system we are already using for the hostel complaints.

Instructions on usage:
For students:
You will need to apply for leave to your warden, every time you are leaving
the campus, and do not expect to come back the same day (For example, a few
hours trip to Dharwad does not require you to apply for a leave. But going
home and coming back the next day does require a leave application.). To
apply for a leave,
1) Go to http://fromabctill.xyz/iitdh/
2) In the top right, you should see a tab name "Leave Requests". Click on
it.
3) Fill in all the fields, including the dates you will be on leave, the
reason for leave, and the place you are going to. Click Submit.
4) Once your warden approves or rejects your request, you will receive a
mail in your iitdh inbox.

Please contact the GSHA or me in case of any queries.

And a round of applause for Harshal Gajjar for setting up a very
user-friendly and intuitive system!

Regards,
Rajshekar

-- 
Rajshekar K
Assistant Professor
Department of Computer Science and Engineering
Indian Institute of Technology Dharwad
Dharwad, Karnataka, India.
Ph: +91-836-2212-888
www.cse.iitd.ac.in/~rajshekar

Dear Prof. Seshu,

TAPMI in collaboration with the Max Planck Institute for Human Development,
Berlin and the Southampton Business School, UK is putting together the *third
edition **of the* ‚Äú*Winter School on Bounded Rationality‚Äù* from January
14-20, 2019 at Manipal. It would be great help if you can pass on this
information to PhD and post-doctoral scholars, early career researchers,
and other interested colleagues.




We are particularly interested in interdisciplinary areas of research in
judgment and decision-making. This year, we are collaborating with the

discussions on behavioral sciences with the industry.

content.200:
Subject: Announcing the Git@IITDh service
Text: Dear All,

Git is an open-source version control system that is essential for any
project. It helps maintain versions of changes made to files, allowing
teams to work in parallel, and allowing rolling back to a known safe state
when things don‚Äôt go as planned. Though commonly used in software projects,
git may be used for any project that involves modification of files. For
example, co-authors of a research paper can use git.

IITDh CCS provides a centralized git server that will allow developers to
maintain a version of their project centrally, and also share the project
with fellow developers. The service will be available from outside the
campus as well.


Please see the attached how-to document for help on usage.


Regards,

Rajshekar

-- 
[on behalf of]
Faculty in Charge
Computing and Communication Services
IIT Dharwad

Text: ---------- Forwarded message ---------

Subject: Fwd: Special Award Announcement: Studio Clockwork Style Award 2019
To: Dean Student Welfare <dean.sw@iitdh.ac.in>




---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Formula Bharat <formulabharat@mobilityeng.in>
Date: Wed, 3 Oct 2018 at 1:07 PM
Subject: Special Award Announcement: Studio Clockwork Style Award 2019
To:


[image: SCW-imagery.jpg]

Studio Clockwork <https://www.studioclockwork.com/> is pleased to announce
the Studio Clockwork Style Award 2019 as a Special Award at the Formula
Bharat 2019 competition.

Studio Clockwork <https://www.studioclockwork.com/> is a cutting edge
digital design company based in Mumbai. The company specializes in 3D
modelling, 3D rendering and animation, and caters to various fields such as
Product design, Transportation design, Architectural designs and Multimedia
content.

As a part of this award, the company is looking for the team which has used
a holistic approach towards the design aesthetic of their Formula Student
vehicle. The winning team ideally shows technical solutions that are both
great-looking and balanced with form and function, coupled with a high
level of presentation and professionalism. The winner of the Studio
Clockwork Style Award 2019 will receive a 3D printed Award and gets to
collaborate with Studio Clockwork for 1 year as an advisor for vehicle
styling and design.

The deadline for document submission towards this award is December 15,
2018. The submission link will be made available on
www.formulabharat.com/deadlines.

2019.  *

Dear Colleagues,

A Workshop on Practical Adaptive Control by Prof. Anuradha Annaswamy (MIT,
USA) will be conducted at IIT Madras from Jan. 21 to Jan. 25, 2019 as a
part of the 2019 International Graduate School in Control (IGSC).

This and a few other workshops are conducted (annually) by the EECI
(European Embedded Control Institute) and IFAC (International Federation of
Automatic Control) with top researchers in the respective fields as the
resource persons.

Please enrol / register for this workshop by Dec. 31, 2019. Follow the link
http://www.eeci-igsc.eu (given in the flyer) for this purpose.
PRESENTATION <http://www.eeci-igsc.eu/>
www.eeci-igsc.eu
The European Embedded Control Institute (EECI) is founded in 2006 in the
framework of the HYCON Network of Excellence (FP6-IST-511368), a funded EC
project from September 2004 to September 2008. EECI is a "lightweight"
association (under the French Association Law 1901), based on volunteer
work by its members.

Request you also to share this information with your colleagues and fellow
learners who might be interested in this course!

Thank you very much.

best,
Arun

content.218:
Subject: Modelling of Reinforced Polymers: Talk by Dr. Ajay Bangalore Harish
Text:  Dear all,

All are cordially invited to attend the following talk.

*Title*:  Modelling of Reinforced Polymers .

*Speaker*: Dr. Ajay Bangalore Harish , Group Leader  ‚ÄúNanomechanics‚Äù at the
Institute of Continuum Mechanics of Leibniz Universit√§t Hannover (LUH)

*Room No*.: 119
*Date*: November 16, 2018 (Friday)
*Time*: 3 pm - 4pm

*Abstract*:

In this presentation, we discuss three main aspects related to modelling of
reinforced polymers:
(a) Computational modelling of complex process
(b) Automated approaches in computational modelling
(c) Role of nanomechanical experiments in answering fundamental questions

Nanoparticle reinforced polymers (or otherwise commonly known as filled
elastomers) are extensively used in several industrial applications,
especially tyres. Just in the year 2015-16, over five billion tyres were
sold worldwide. Considering, a single passenger tyre loses about 1.5Kg in
weight during its lifetime, this is atleast 7.5 million tonnes of
particulate content added into our atmosphere in a single year. These
particulate content no only consists of carbon but also heavy metals like
mercury that are used during the compounding process. Considering that the
first pneumatic tyres were made in 1888, it is unfortunate, that with after
1.5 centuries our knowledge of rubber friction, wear, adhesion etc. is
rudimentary at best. Most of the works particularly related to wear, till
date, include adhoc parameter-driven non-transferable models based on
Archard Wear Law or a modified form of it.

Filled elastomers are complicated materials and their behaviour span
several temporal and spatial length scales. In addition, they demonstrate
several nonlinear phenomenon like large deformation, viscous behaviour,
temperature dependence, Mullins, Payne‚Äôs effect etc. On one end, the
modelling approaches are dominated by statistical models while on the other
are homogenized macroscale models. To this day, there have been several
phenomenological models, with as many as over 25 parameters, that intend to
capture all these in a single scale. In this work, we focus on the
microscale modelling of filled elastomers where we consider the
decomposition of the complex process of abrasive wear into a multitude of
aspects including geometric description, contact-induced fracture and crack
propagation. The developed computational model is used to investigate the
influence of filler concentration on the abrasive wear behaviour.

While building such computational models are highly time-consuming, in this
work, we have leveraged the power of automated computational modelling
approaches to ensure speedy and accurate models that demonstrate quadratic
convergence. Finally, the pressing questions remains about the accuracy of
such models and lack of techniques to validate them. We use Nanoindentation
to provide experimental insights to try to answer some fundamental
questions like ‚ÄúWhy do cracks initiate? What causes them to propagate? What
causes adhesive behaviour in elastomers? Can adhesion initiate cracks?‚Äù
etc. that will provide credence to the developed computational models.


*Bio*:
Dr.-Ing. Ajay Bangalore Harish is a Group Leader ‚ÄúNanomechanics‚Äù at the
Institute of Continuum Mechanics of Leibniz Universit√§t Hannover (LUH)
since 2018. LUH is one of the members of the TU9 ‚Äì a consortium of the top
nine technical universities of Germany. He has been awarded his PhD (2018)
at LUH Hannover under the advice of Prof. Dr.-Ing. habil. Peter Wriggers;
Masters in Aeronautics from California Institute of Technology (USA); and
Bachelors in Mechanical Engineering from National Institute of Technology
Karnataka (India).

 Alongside, his academic pursuit, he has been co-founder of two engineering
start-up‚Äôs with focus on CAE. During 2016-17, he was the co-founder & CTO
of SYmbosim Inc. which focused on developed of high-fidelity tools for
composite tailoring. The start-up was one of the seven selected to be a
part of Airbus‚Äôs BizLab accelerator program. Transitioning from SYmbosim,
since Aug-2017, he has been the co-founder and CEO of Engineer Materials
Inc. EM launched a platform called ‚ÄúIntelligent Simulation Hub for
Engineers‚Äù (ISHI) that is aimed at making CAE attractive to small & medium
scale businesses and particularly for the Indian market. ISHI combines the
power of Artificial Intelligence (AI), Machine Learning (ML) & Augmented
Reality (AR) with advanced element technologies that render real-time
simulations.

*Participation from 2nd and 3rd year ME students is highly encouraged.*


*With best regards*
*Tejas*

> Abstract:

> accompanying software, towards design of parts and structures with a high
> degree of numerical precision. Target application domains include design of
> automobiles, aircrafts and buildings, among others. In this talk we discuss
> two kernel level modeling primitives.
> First, we propose a comprehensive algorithmic framework for computation of
> solid sweeps. This involves computing the boundary of the swept volume
> generated by moving the input solid along the input one-parameter-family of
> rigid motions in three dimensional space. In particular, we  discuss local

> Several examples from a prototype implementation in the ACIS modeling

> Second, we demonstrate a robust computational interface for precise

content.220:
Subject: Friday 9 August, Talk by Dr. Jinesh on Two Modeling Primitives for Computer Aided Geometric Design
Text: Dear All,

We will have a talk by Dr. Jinesh Machchhar on 9th August 2019 at 2 PM in
Room No. 115.
All are cordially invited to attend the talk.

Title: Two Modeling Primitives for Computer Aided Geometric Design

Abstract:
Computer Aided Geometric Design concerns development of algorithms and
accompanying software, towards design of parts and structures with a high
degree of numerical precision. Target application domains include design of
automobiles, aircrafts and buildings, among others. In this talk we discuss
two kernel level modeling primitives.
First, we propose a comprehensive algorithmic framework for computation of
solid sweeps. This involves computing the boundary of the swept volume
generated by moving the input solid along the input one-parameter-family of
rigid motions in three dimensional space. In particular, we  discuss local
issues such as the parametrization of the boundary surface, detection and
elimination of self-intersections, as well as global issues such as
body-check and the topological data associated with the swept volume.
Several examples from a prototype implementation in the ACIS modeling
kernel will be shown. Applications include CNC machining verification,
product handling and collision detection.
Second, we demonstrate a robust computational interface for precise
modeling of microstructures towards 3D printing. This is achieved through
functional composition of B-spline functions and allows separate design of
the micro and the macro structures of an object. In particular, we
demonstrate construction of recursive, fractal-like microstructures which
are composed of trivariate tiles with C0-discontinuities. Applications
include design of porous and composite materials.
This is joint work with Milind Sohoni, Bharat Adsul and Gershon Elber.

Speaker bio:
Jinesh is a researcher in the field of computer aided geometric design. His
areas of interest include solid modeling and shape analysis. He obtained
his PhD from IIT Bombay and thereafter was a post doctoral fellow at
Technion - Israel Institute of Technology.

-- 
Thanks,

Kedar Khandeparkar
Dept. Computer Science and Engg.
IIT Dharwad
content.221:
Subject: Re:
Text: Dear All:
   Dr. Jagannath Raju, Chief Technology Officer, Systemantics Pvt. Limited,
is scheduled to visit IIT Dharwad tomorrow. Holding masters and PhD degree
from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, USA, he is a
renowned technologist in the field of robotics in India. He will deliver a
talk tomorrow as per the following schedule. The Venue for the talk would
be informed by evening. Students are urged to interact with him and explore
opportunities in the area of robotics.

Title: "From Lab to Market - Crossing the divide"
Speaker: Dr. Jagannath Raju
Time: 2:00 PM to 3:00 PM

Abstract of the talk:
The challenge of taking a technology hardware product from a lab prototype
to a commercially viable value proposition is daunting within the Indian
eco-system. It is even more so when the product, as in the robotics domain,
is multi-disciplinary in nature and entails diverse skill sets across
design, development, manufacturing, sales and service. Problem solving
skills that need to be developed beyond the classroom to address real-world
issues will be illustrated with a few case studies across multiple
disciplines. At a higher level the fundamentals in our eco-system that
impede the full intellectual potential of India to be leveraged to realize
globally competitive products can be debated.

Short biography of the speaker:
Dr. Jagannath Raju is the Chief Technology Officer of Systemantics, and is
responsible for the company‚Äôs product development and technology strategy.
He incubates product ideas based on market requirements and leads their
development into full-fledged products. His consulting experience in the
USA covers development of innovative robotic systems for space, underwater
and hazardous applications for projects funded by NASA, Federal Sea Grant
Program, Department of Energy and the National Science Foundation. He also
served as a consultant in the Boston area to many companies involved in
robotics and automation R&D, especially in semiconductor fabrication and
handling, and was a visiting scientist at the Mechanical Engineering
Laboratory, Tsukuba, Japan under a fellowship from Japan‚Äôs Ministry of
International Trade and Industry.

After relocating back to India in 1994 he worked as a consultant to the
Center for Artificial Intelligence and Robotics, Bangalore for the
development of a controller for a robotic inspection platform before
founding Systemantics in 1995. His expertise covers many areas of
technology relevant to robotic systems, viz., mechanical design, actuator
and sensors, computer control, signal and power electronics and embedded
and application software. Jagannath is a B Tech from the Indian Institute
of Technology, Madras, and holds a master‚Äôs degree from the University of
California, Berkeley, CA, USA, and master‚Äôs & doctoral degrees from the

content.233:
Subject: Important dates notes for election 2019
Text: Hi everyone

The last dates for the following things are:
1. Joining clubs: 10th March
2. To submit your name for contesting for a post: 15th March
3. To submit your manifesto: 16th March
4. To withdraw your name from contesting: 20th March

Some important notes:
1. Only 2nd year, 3rd year and Phd students can contest for the general
secretary positions.
2. All students can contest for all clubs secretaries (cultural, technical,
sports clubs) posts, hostel secretaries posts and as CRs.
3. While submitting your manifestos please submit a photo of yourself as
well.
4. Students who are contesting cannot do an door to door campaigning in the
hostels. No campaigning in the Academic area.
5. Students can only paste 2 posters, one in front of each mess.
6. Election Council members cannot contest for any post.
7. If you are interested to be a part of any club. Do it before the last
date that is 10th March. The club may have any type of filtering process to
entering the club, but all students should be given an opportunity to join
the club.

If there is any further information regarding elections it will conveyed by
email.

-- 
Regards

ASHRITH ADEPU
Gen. Secy Hostel Affairs

content.239:
Subject: Fwd: IIT Dharwad | InOut 6.0
Text: Sonu Sourav
General Secretary, Technical Affairs
IIT Dharwad


---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Public Relation Office <pro@iitdh.ac.in>
Date: Wed, Aug 28, 2019 at 1:20 PM
Subject: Fwd: IIT Dharwad | InOut 6.0
To: General Secretary Technical Affairs <gstech@iitdh.ac.in>



---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Deevanshu Kumawat <deevanshu1997@gmail.com>
Date: Wed, Aug 28, 2019, 13:01
Subject: IIT Dharwad | InOut 6.0
To: <pro@iitdh.ac.in>
Cc: <placement@iitdh.ac.in>


Greetings,

As an organizer and representative of InOut 6.0 <http://hackinout.co/>, I
would like to inform you about the event.

Scheduled to be organized on October 19, 2019 - October 20, 2019, in
Bangalore, InOut is India‚Äôs biggest community Hackathon, the first of its
kind. The 48-hours event will feature developers from IITs, IIITs, NITs and
many more Institutes from across the nation competing and innovating to
build software and hardware solutions such as mobile apps and websites, to
name a few. We will also be organizing a conference on the first day where
students will get to hear and learn from the best in the tech industry.
Spread across the weekend, the event will prove to be a great networking
ground for the budding student developers as well.

Also, the following perks make it a must-attend for the technologically
inclined:


   - Registrations for the hackathon are free of cost.
   - Selected students will also get access to the conference on the first
   day at no cost.
   - The organizers will take care of travel reimbursements for accepted
   students.
   - With a host of companies and startups in tow as past sponsors,
   including Google, Facebook, Twitter, Cloudflare, Dropbox, IBM, PhonePe,
   Intel, DigitalOcean, GitHub, GitLab, Razorpay, Y Combinator and the likes,
   the event will provide the students with the perfect platform to grab
   potential jobs/internships.
   - A lot of cool merchandises/schwag will be provided to all the
   participants (free of cost).


5th October 2019 11:59 pm IST is the last date for registration. It can be
done through Devfolio available on  <https://hackinout.co/>
*https://hackinout.co/* <https://hackinout.co/>. The organizing team looks
forward to the participation of your esteemed Institution‚Äôs developers,
designers and entrepreneurs in the event.

Please circulate the mail on the relevant channels, as you seem fit.
Kind Regards!

--
Deevanshu
Team InOut

content.243:
Subject: ANSYS Software Installation Procedure and Training
Text: Dear all,

Happy new year 2019!

The Institute has purchased licenses for ANSYS Software
namely, ANSYS Mechanical (Structural/Stress analysis),
ANSYS CFD (Fluid dynamics and Heat Transfer analysis),
ANSYS HFSS (3D Electromagnetic Field Simulator for RF & Wireless Design)
ANSYS Chemkin (Chemical kinetics for chemical reactions).

The ANSYS software can be installed on Windows, RHEL, CentOS (recommended
platforms) as well as Ubuntu.

For efficient usage, a machine with Intel i7 and a minimum 8GB of RAM
is suggested.

The software can be installed on individual PCs, however, the license should
be fetched from within IIT Dharwad via the license manager.

The procedure to install the software is attached herewith.

The training from the supplier, Entuple Technologies has been arranged as
per below (room no. 24, Ground floor, Computer Lab) and you are welcome to
attend and *derive maximum benefit from the same*.

January 5th and 6th: Training on ANSYS Mech
January 12th: Training on ANSYS HFSS
January 19th and 20th: Training on ANSYS CFD

The training is open to whoever is interested and learn.

However, to understand the logistics requirements, we request you to
please fill up the below form if interested to attend.

https://goo.gl/forms/7HmMTmlirRRKg3qV2

Regards,
Dhiraj.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Dr. Dhiraj V. Patil
Assistant Professor (Homepage
<https://sites.google.com/site/dvpmultiplefluidsatiitmandi/>)
Department of Mechanical Engineering,
Indian Institute of Technology Dharwad.
Dharwad - 580011, Karnataka, India.
O: 8362212829

content.245:
Subject: Design and development of nanosatellites by IEEE DSU SB from 3 to 5 July 2019
Text: Dear Students,

IEEE is organizing a 3 day workshop on Design and Development of Nano
Satellites from 3rd to 5th July. Please find the details below.
--
Regards,
Naveen Kadayinti


---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: IEEE eNotice <enotice@ieee.org>
Date: Thu, 25 Apr 2019 at 09:34
Subject: Design and development of nanosatellites by IEEE DSU SB from 3 to
5 July 2019


If you are having trouble reading this message, click here
<http://enotice.ieee.org/link.cfm?r=m5gKvmzLaPvcXzXh0lAvNQ~~&pe=Cnytirs3RkTtkbATCOk6QS2WWpuE37D0OKCfhoqfO1QEm4NZ3oiKhO5Erc9Lil9qzf6w2TMRTh7xtA8AOcpYTA~~&t=TNL_9JCi5MEfaGRD2Ja6_Q~~>
for the web version.
Dear IEEE Members,
Greetings from IEEE student branch of Dayananda Sagar University (DSU)
Bangalore!
It gives us immense pleasure to inform you that Dayananda Sagar University,
Bangalore is organizing a three day workshop on Design and Development of
Nano Satellite during 3 rd July to 5th July 2019. This event will be
organized in collaboration with Planet Aerospace and IEEE Bangalore
Section.

All the speakers for this workshop are senior scientists from ISRO and they
are having very rich experience in Satellite Technologies. I take this
opportunity to request you and your Students/Faculties to participate in
this workshop.

We are happy to inform that Dr. P.S. Goel has kindly consented to be the
Chief Guest of the inaugural session. We request you to kindly circulate
this information to all faculty and students of your college.
Brochure of workshop can be found in the link
https://tinyurl.com/nanosatellite-DSU-Brochure
<http://enotice.ieee.org/link.cfm?r=m5gKvmzLaPvcXzXh0lAvNQ~~&pe=UFzhgbB_O8y2JlQyQM7EhgNSxtGfQ8sF2Ku1ekpPBodWE5UEWZxLAv6GR_qUgN7TaJ5MCjJ0tH_MTV4YKWg-CQ~~&t=TNL_9JCi5MEfaGRD2Ja6_Q~~>
Detailed information of the workshop is available at
https://www.dsu.edu.in/nano-satellites/
<http://enotice.ieee.org/link.cfm?r=m5gKvmzLaPvcXzXh0lAvNQ~~&pe=VektdTOcm_grBR-mlUx4Gt9_rukPfrVDDhHLU0y9Fgw6YYNPHfMenaHe9jUsvS7Lgv4MD8c-Wp29EUhQgJqXCw~~&t=TNL_9JCi5MEfaGRD2Ja6_Q~~>



Looking forward for the great participation and learning.


-- 
With warm regards.....

*Dr. Pushpa Mala S, *
*Assistant Professor,*
*Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering,*
*Dayananda Sagar University,*
*Bangalore-560068.*
*Ph:+91-9986911191*
Bangalore Section : http://www.ieeebangalore.org
<http://enotice.ieee.org/link.cfm?r=m5gKvmzLaPvcXzXh0lAvNQ~~&pe=_f2FyzIfXzKLvKZUf5aGH7rKg8E6OBS_uzjIM-HseZBMqiP9ydPBo95ofgfoZnNr5ZLlzYS-RERkZpt_5DZChg~~&t=TNL_9JCi5MEfaGRD2Ja6_Q~~>

content.246:
Subject: GK Quiz
Text: Hi Everyone!

We are proud to announce a GK Quiz being organised in the college for all
you guys and girls!

The Preliminary round will be held on Friday, 24th August, at 8:30pm in
Room 120. The best performers will move on to the next round.

The rules for the preliminary round are given below:
1) Participation for the event will be in teams of two (no more, no less)
2) It will be a written round. A sheet of paper will be provided to you.
Please bring a pen to the venue.
3) The round consists of 20 questions.
4) As the title suggests, the questions will be based on General Knowledge.
5) Each question will be read out loud and the teams will be given a time
of 90 seconds to answer it. Each question will be repeated once in the end.
6) Use of unfair means will result in disqualification.
7) Communication between teams will result in disqualification for both
teams.
8) Quiz Master's decision will be final.
9) Please ask the volunteers on duty for any queries during the quiz.

Click here <https://goo.gl/forms/fTRUdTmCrGDyrIDU2> to register for the
quiz!

The registrations will be open till 8:30pm, August 24th. Please note that
on the spot registration will not be accepted.

We hope to see you at the preliminary round!

Thanks and Regards,
Mehul Bose
General Cultural Secretary

Subject: Re: Please share your Poems and Short Essays for Matribhasha Diwas or International Mother Language Day
Text: Dear Sir,

That sounds great. In fact, the very purpose of the Matribhasha Diwas is to
have writing/discussion/deliberation in as many languages as possible,
irrespective of the number of users. Besides, there are many expressions
and ideas that are more succinctly captured in one's Mother Tongue.

I am sure your entry in Tulu will be a treat for all those who can read the
language.

Regards,
Ridhima
