content.1166:
Subject: Beware of Phishing Scams - reg.
Text: Dear All,

Nowadays there are a lot of *Phishing s*cams happening globally on
institutional websites and mail servers. Since nobody wants to fall prey to
a phishing scam, I would like to share you some basic information and
guidelines in keeping yourself safe.



*Phishing* is a fraudulent attempt to obtain sensitive information such as
usernames, passwords, and other personal details by disguising as a
trustworthy entity in electronic communication. Typically carried out
by email spoofing or instant messaging, it often directs users to enter
personal information at a fake website, the look and feel of which are
identical to the legitimate site. Users are often lured by communications
purporting to be from trusted parties. Thus everyone should be very careful
while using the internet and accessing emails in your inbox.



*Instructions to Avoid Phishing Scams*



   - Do not disclose your *E-Mail*/*LDAP* login credentials to anyone (ie:
   - *Username* & *Password*).
   - Do not enter your login credentials on any unknown websites.
   - Do not enter login credentials in any anonymous pop-up windows.
   - Do not readily click on links in emails from unknown sources -
   Instead, roll your mouse pointer over the link to reveal its true
   destination, displayed in the bottom left corner of your screen. Beware if
   this is different from what is displayed in the text of the link from the
   email.
   - Do not copy an unknown link from these kinds of spam emails and paste
   them on your web browsers - These links are made to look very humble by the
   phishers but they will actually land you to some scam and fraud sites.
   - Be careful about opening or saving any document or attachment that
   come with spam emails - Do not trust these kinds of emails even if they
   appear to be sent by some authorized entity.
   - Never ever send your confidential information about your account in an
   email.
   - Do not respond to emails from unknown sources. Check junk mail folders
   regularly in case a legitimate email gets through by mistake.
   - Do not open or forward emails which you suspect as being scams.
   - Keep your browser up to date ‚Äì Security patches are released for
   popular browsers, in response to the security loopholes that phishers
   and other hackers inevitably discover and exploit.
   - Please report immediately on *ccsop@iitdh.ac.in <ccsop@iitdh.ac.in>* if
   you receive any such email.
   - Immediately change your passwords if you have accidentally revealed
   your credentials.
   - *CCS Operator* do not send any such emails to our user community.



*A Phishing email typically looks similar to the below one:-*

*________________________________________*
From: support@iitdh.ac.in
Sent: Thu, Mar 15, 2019
Subject: UPGRADE EMAIL ACCOUNT
We are currently upgrading our Server for our Account Holders. In order to
upgrade your account, you need to assist us by sending the information
below or else your Account might be lost.
Provide the below information :
User Name :
Pass Word :
Regards,
ADMIN, IIT Dharwad
*________________________________________*



Please note that the email cited above is a spurious one, trying to get
your email credentials so that the same can be used to get access to your
email account. Even the Sender's  Email ID may appear to be originating
from IITDH, please do not respond to any such email as it is a phishing
attempt made by an external entity. *You are requested to ignore all such
emails without responding to them as they are fraudulent attempts **by
PHISHERS & other HACKERS **to steal your password so as to be able to hack
into your email account.*



Thanks and Regards..!



Vince Vincent M

Executive Technical Assistant ,
Computer Center , IIT Dharwad .

content.1171:
Subject: APS: Monika Bai
Text: Dear all,

Ms. Monika Bai will give her annual progress seminar (APS) tomorrow at 3
pm. The other details are as follows:

Title: Pyrene K-region Arylation via C-H Activation Pathways
Date: Tuesday, 23rd July at 3 pm.
Venue: Classroom 21
Abstract:
In an era of rapid technology, electronics have gained high importance.
However, the 3D metal-semiconductors used wherein are rigid, inflexible and
also demands high-temperature processing. The organic congeners (œÄ-conjugated
molecules) on the other hand overcomes this shortcoming and possess similar
electronic properties. Thus, the library of conjugated systems is already
reported, but the need for versatile and economically viable methodology to
develop such molecules is of today‚Äôs prime interest. Along those lines, C-H
activation-functionalization pathway is chosen as the efficient method due
to its atom and steps economical methodology and direct functionalization
dominating over conventional methods where toxic reagents and many
steps processing
is required to functionalize the building blocks. The Evolving research is
utilizing C-H activation to access inert sites of pyrene, anthracene and
other conjugated systems. In this report, the importance of œÄ-conjugated
systems is studied and pyrene K-region which is electronically less
reactive is functionalized with aryl substitution via C-H activation
using palladium
catalyst, silver additives, and inexpensive glycine as a directing group.

Best wishes,
Rajesh

-- 
Dr. Rajeswara Rao Malakalapalli,
Department of Chemistry,
Indian Institute of Technology Dharwad,
Dharwad-580011.
Ph: +91 836 2212 834
content.1172:
Subject: TechFesia2018 Invitation at IIIT Sri City on 21st and 22nd September
Text: Greetings!!!


Indian Institute of Information Technology (IIIT), Sri City presents its
technical fest "TechFesia" on 21st and 22nd September 2018.

TechFesia, a two-day gathering of creative minds at the Indian Institute of
Information Technology, Sri City, Chittoor, debuts this year. TechFesia
2018 marks the beginning of an exceptionally ambitious annual technology
fest. Packed with competitions in some of the most promising fields of
Tech, it showcases the epitome of the future of technology. From Artificial
Intelligence and Cryptography to Healthcare and Robotics, TechFesia has it
all.

The focal points of TechFesia 2018 are the two hackathons, MedTech
Hackathon and TopBot. These competitions challenge the participants to make
tangible progress in rapidly developing areas of technology. TechFesia aims
to match up to state-of-the-art industry standards which will be
facilitated by industry professionals providing their knowledge and
expertise as mentors and external judges for the competitions.

TechFesia 2018 has following Hackathons, IT Events and Drone workshop:

*           EVENT NAME*

*          EVENT TYPE*

01.  MedTech Hackathon

          IoT/AI/Software

02.  TopBot (Hackathon)

          Artificial Intelligence

03.  Reverse Coding

          Programming

04.  Hack the Code

          Programming

05.  Elektra 3.0

          Programming

06.  Cascader

          Web Development

07.  Appathon

          App Development

08.  Racing Car Event

          Hardware

09.  Pravikarsha

          Logo Design

10.  Capture the Flag

          Networking & Cryptography

11.  Drone/Quadrotor Workshop

          Hardware/Software/UAV



Please find the more details in attached TechFesia brochure and at:
http://techfesia.iiits.in/events


We on the behalf of the Indian Institute of Information Technology, Sri
City cordially invite the students of your esteemed institute to our first
ever technical fest - "Techfesia" on 21st and 22nd 2018.

Here, we request you to please circulate it among your students and please
make sure to send at least one team from your institute.
We will take care of local transport in Sri City, Accommodation and Fooding
of your students.

Student Coordinators: Mr. Krishna Kumar Dey (techfesia@iiits.in,
krishnakumar.d16@iiits.in, +91-8804837737)

content.1174:
Subject: Talk by Prof. Gautam Kalghatgi, Visiting Professor (Oxford University and Imperial College London) on Jan. 9th 2019
Text:  Dear all,

All are cordially invited to attend the following talk.

*Title*: Is it really the end of internal combustion engines and petroleum
in transport?

*Speaker*: Prof. Gautam Kalghatgi,
Visiting Professor at Oxford University (Engineering Science)
and also at Imperial College London (Mechanical Engineering, UK

*Room No*.: 203
*Date*: January 09, 2019 (Wednesday)
*Time*: 4.00pm - 5.00pm

*Abstract*: Transport is almost entirely (99.9%) powered by internal
combustion engines (ICEs) burning petroleum-derived liquid fuels (95%) and
the global demand for transport energy is large and is increasing. The
alternatives to ICEs and conventional fuels start from a very low base and
face significant environmental and other barriers to fast and unrestrained
growth. For instance, there is speculation that transport could be rapidly
and fully electrified.  However commercial transport, which accounts for
over 50% of transport energy use, is very difficult or impossible to
electrify. To replace even all light duty vehicles (LDVs) by battery
electric vehicles (BEVs) requires the numbers of BEVs to increase by
perhaps a thousand-fold on a global scale. The greenhouse gas (GHG) impact
of BEVs would be worse than that of conventional vehicles if electricity
generation and the energy used for battery production are not sufficiently
decarbonized. If coal continues to be a part of the energy mix, as it will
in China and India, and if power generation is near urban centres, even
local air quality in terms of particulates, nitrogen oxides and sulphur
dioxide would get worse. The human toxicity impacts associated with battery
production are large and cannot be ignored as they currently are. If
governments wish to force a change to BEVs, very large investments in
charging infrastructure and electricity generation will be needed. There
will be additional costs in the short term associated with various
subsidies required to promote such a change and in the longer term, the
loss of revenue from fuel taxes which contribute significantly to public
finances in most countries.  Internal combustion engines will continue to
power transport, particularly commercial transport, to a very large degree
for decades to come and will continue to improve. There will also be a role
for low-carbon and other alternative fuels where they make sense. However,
such alternatives also start from a low base and face constraints on rapid
and unlimited growth so that they are not expected to make up much more
than 10% of the total transport energy demand by 2040. In the longer term,
as GHG-free electricity generation is greatly expanded and battery
technology improves there will be an increasing role for BEVs and the
required charging and recycling infrastructure will evolve. Meanwhile,
there will certainly be increasing electrification, particularly of LDVs in
the form of hybridization to improve ICEs.

*Bio*:
Gautam Kalghatgi is currently a Visiting Professor at Oxford University
(Engineering Science) and also at Imperial College London (Mechanical
Engineering)
and in the past, at KTH Stockholm, TU Eindhoven and Sheffield University.
He is a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering, SAE (Society of
Automotive
Engineers), I.Mech.E. and the Combustion Institute and an Honorary Fellow
of the International Society for Energy Environment and Sustainability.
He worked for 31 years at Shell Research followed by 8 years in Saudi
Aramco before retiring in June 2018. He has published extensively,
including a book -
‚ÄúFuel/Engine Interactions‚Äù - on combustion, fuels, transport energy and
engine research. He has a B.Tech. from I.I.T. Bombay (1972) and a Ph.D.
from
Bristol University (1975) in Aeronautical Engineering and did post-doctoral
research on turbulent combustion at Southampton University (1975-1979)
before
joining Shell Research.

Contact email: Kalghatgig@gmail.com
[image: image.png]

*Participation encouraged: 1st, 2nd and 3rd year ME, EE students.*

*It will be nice to listen to Professor Kalghatgi on ICEs and BEVs.*

Thank you,
Sincerely,
Dhiraj.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Dr. Dhiraj V. Patil
Assistant Professor (Homepage
<https://sites.google.com/site/dvpmultiplefluidsatiitmandi/>)
Department of Mechanical Engineering,
Indian Institute of Technology Dharwad.
Dharwad - 580011, Karnataka, India.

of us. The hacks were really amazing and have huge future potential. I
would like to thank our institute for giving us this opportunity to
organize this event. The event could not have been possible without the

and TAs who helped to make this event a grand success. A special thanks to

meal .

*IIT Dharwad*

Text: ---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: OnkarGopal Marathe <onkar.marathe@gov.in>
Date: Sat, Dec 15, 2018 at 1:50 PM
Subject: Fwd: A request to share the information about All India Youth
Conference 'Jagruti'19' on the theme of "Sustainable Rural Habitat"
(commmemorating 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi) scheduled to be
organized at IISc on 12 & 13 Jan 2019
To:




-------- Original Message --------
From: *Students' Council Chairman *<chair.sc@iisc.ac.in>
Date: Dec 7, 2018 10:23:12 PM
Subject: A request to share the information about All India Youth
Conference 'Jagruti'19' on the theme of "Sustainable Rural Habitat"
(commmemorating 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi) scheduled to be
organized at IISc on 12 & 13 Jan 2019
To: "onkar.marathe@gov.in" <onkar.marathe@gov.in>

Dear Sir,

Greetings from the Indian Institute of Science (IISc), Bangalore!


It gives me an immense pleasure to let you know about the 'Jagruti'19' an
All India Youth Conference that is to be organized by the Students'
Council, IISc and Think India at Indian Institute of Science on 12th & 13th
January 2019 commemorating 150th BirhAnnivrary of Mahatma Gandhi. The theme
of the conference is "Sustainable Rural Habitat- Returning to our Roots".
The national level competitions and thought-provoking sessions by
eminent experts and personalities will be organised to make the conference

content.1198:
Subject: Fwd: Workshop on "Automation in FEA" at IIT Madras (23 - 27 Aug, 2019)
Text: ---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Dr.-Ing. Ajay B Harish <harish@ikm.uni-hannover.de>
Date: Mon, Jul 29, 2019 at 5:09 PM
Subject: Workshop on "Automation in FEA" at IIT Madras (23 - 27 Aug, 2019)
To: Manoj Pandey <mpandey@iitm.ac.in>


*Dear Colleagues,*

I would like to cordially invite you and your students / Post-docs to the
workshop "*Automation in FEA*" to be held at *IIT Madras* between *23 - 27
August (2019)*. Please note that the date for early registration is *31st
July 2019*. All information can be found on the website:
*www.ajaybharish.com/automate-fea
<http://www.ajaybharish.com/automate-fea>*

*Content of Workshop*

This workshop will introduce the participants to *finite element methods
and its applications *to linear and nonlinear problems related to *solid
mechanics* and *heat transfer*. The workshop aims to bridge the* gap
between theoretical understanding* and *practical implementation*.
Participants will be exposed to* coding their own solver *using *C++*;
interfacing with* commercial codes like Abaqus & LS-Dyna*; *global
automation* using FreeFEM++; *local automation* using Mathematica; using
*opensource* for all your simulation needs.

The course is divided into* three parts*: Basic modules (Day 01 & 02),
Advanced modules (Day 03 & 04) and Optional project module (Day 05).

*Intended audience*

This course is suitable for both *students (final year bachelor onwards)*
and* industry professionals* who are interested in modeling using Finite
Element Method. Participants are expected to have a basic knowledge of
strength of materials, basic solid mechanics & elasticity, continuum
mechanics and heat transfer. A working knowledge about finite element
methods is a bonus. *Participants* are expected to bring their *own laptop*
to complete the laboratory modules.

*Important dates*

The early registration date is *31st July 2019*. The last date for
registration is *15th August 2019*. Please note that there is *no on-spot
registration*.

*Contact Information*

Enclosed along is a* detailed schedule* & would request you to kindly
circulate to anyone interested in your department. I would be glad if your
students would be interested in participating in the workshop.

Please feel free to* email Dr. Manoj Pandey (Manoj) or me *regarding any
queries about the workshop. Looking forward to hearing from you.

Best Regards
Ajay

-- 

Dr. Ajay B. Harish (Ajay)
Institute of Continuum Mechanics
Leibniz Universit√§t Hannover
Appelstrasse 11, 30167 Hannover (Germany)
Phone: +49-511-762-17573
Mail: harish@ikm.uni-hannover.de
Web: http://www.ajaybharish.com
Institute web: http://www.ikm.uni-hannover.de

content.1204:
Subject: A talk by robotics expert Dr. Jagannath Raju
Text: Dear All:
   The venue of the talk by Dr. Jagannath Raju, CTO, Systemantics, between
2:00 PM and 3:00 PM today is room no. 119. The updated notice is given
below. I hope to see many of you in the talk.





Title: "From Lab to Market - Crossing the divide"
Speaker: Dr. Jagannath Raju
Time: 2:00 PM to 3:00 PM
Venue Room No. 119

Abstract of the talk:
The challenge of taking a technology hardware product from a lab prototype
to a commercially viable value proposition is daunting within the Indian
eco-system. It is even more so when the product, as in the robotics domain,
is multi-disciplinary in nature and entails diverse skill sets across
design, development, manufacturing, sales and service. Problem solving
skills that need to be developed beyond the classroom to address real-world
issues will be illustrated with a few case studies across multiple
disciplines. At a higher level the fundamentals in our eco-system that
impede the full intellectual potential of India to be leveraged to realize
globally competitive products can be debated.

Short biography of the speaker:
Dr. Jagannath Raju is the Chief Technology Officer of Systemantics, and is
responsible for the company‚Äôs product development and technology strategy.
He incubates product ideas based on market requirements and leads their
development into full-fledged products. His consulting experience in the
USA covers development of innovative robotic systems for space, underwater
and hazardous applications for projects funded by NASA, Federal Sea Grant
Program, Department of Energy and the National Science Foundation. He also
served as a consultant in the Boston area to many companies involved in
robotics and automation R&D, especially in semiconductor fabrication and
handling, and was a visiting scientist at the Mechanical Engineering
Laboratory, Tsukuba, Japan under a fellowship from Japan‚Äôs Ministry of
International Trade and Industry.

After relocating back to India in 1994 he worked as a consultant to the
Center for Artificial Intelligence and Robotics, Bangalore for the
development of a controller for a robotic inspection platform before
founding Systemantics in 1995. His expertise covers many areas of
technology relevant to robotic systems, viz., mechanical design, actuator
and sensors, computer control, signal and power electronics and embedded
and application software. Jagannath is a B Tech from the Indian Institute
of Technology, Madras, and holds a master‚Äôs degree from the University of
California, Berkeley, CA, USA, and master‚Äôs & doctoral degrees from the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, USA.


with regards,

people. To use the software registration is necessary and the details are
given below
______________________________ ______________________________

Registration Process :-

Step 2: Click on Join Your Organization button, fill up the self-service
form. Ensure that users are registering from their respective official
email id (*@iitdh.ac.in <http://iitdh.ac.in/>*)
Step 3: After clicking signup, an activation email will be sent to the
user's institutional email ID.

Please Note: Your @edu credential verification has been activated and an
activation email will be sent to the user's institutional email ID once
he/she registers. Users may at times get this in Spam/Junk Folder due to
mail setting - users are advised to check the spam folder in case the link
is not received in the INBOX.

use and can be explored by the user.

Password credentials will grant access to use the Plugin for users.

Dharwad through our partnership with Yourdost.

support.*

<https://yourdost.com/?yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhMail&yd_campaign=Launch&yd_term=19>
Hi There,

Hope you're doing well!

Your journey through college and semester-life must be riddled with so many
questions right? Questions about exams, career, success, relationships and
even yourself. If only it were possible to get a friend who could give you
anonymous, unbiased, round the clock help. Well, look no further, because
we've got just the thing for you.

*IIT Dharwad* is pleased to join hands with *YourDOST*, one of India's
leading online and emotional wellness platforms, to ensure that your
emotional well-being is always looked after.

So how can you and your dependants go about utilising YourDOST's services
for free as a student of IIT Dharwad?
Here's how:

*1. Visit www.yourdost.com
<https://yourdost.com/?yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhMail&yd_campaign=Launch&yd_term=19>*
[image: YourDOST Homepage]
<https://yourdost.com/?yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhMail&yd_campaign=Launch&yd_term=19>


*2. Sign up in a jiffy and be on your way to seeking professional guidance
in no time. Important! - You must signup using your official IIT Dharwad
email id (ending with "@iitdh.ac.in <http://iitdh.ac.in>"**). This will **white
list** your account and make sure that you receive our services for free**.*
[image: Signing Up]
<https://yourdost.com/?yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhMail&yd_campaign=Launch&yd_term=19>

*3. Alternatively, you can sign up with your personal email id Important! -
In this case, you must signup using your college's/hostel's network. Once
that's done you can use YourDOST from any network.*

*4. After verifying your email address, click "Chat Now" to start chatting
with a YourDOST Expert.*

*5. That's all! You can now start chatting with a YourDOST Expert anytime
you want.*
[image: Connect to an expert]

*6. Alternatively, click "Book An Appointment" to book an audio/video
appointment with a YourDOST Expert.*
Should you ever feel the need to open up to someone about your concerns,
remember help is always just a click away. Here's wishing a happier and
healthier future for you.


connect to an expert now
<https://yourdost.com/chatSession/?workgroup=demo@workgroup.chat.yourdost.com&yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhMail&yd_campaign=Launch&yd_term=19>

by *AICTE & Dept. of Science & Technology. *

This Competition would greatly help spread awareness of Intellectual
Property Rights (IPR) and empower the young innovators to protect their
inventions.

IPTSE garnered support from different state governments, Ministry of Micro,
Small & Medium Enterprises, Govt. of India, important education
institutions like All India Council of Technical Education (AICTE),

school and under graduate students at university level.

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Prof. Mahadeva Prasanna <prasanna@iitdh.ac.in>
Date: Thu, Jul 11, 2019 at 10:05 PM
Subject: APS: Jagabandhu Mishra
To: Faculty IIT Dharwad <faculty@iitdh.ac.in>, <staff@iitdh.ac.in>,
Students <students@iitdh.ac.in>
Cc: Bharath B N <bharathbn@iitdh.ac.in>, Dr Naveen M B <naveenmb@iitdh.ac.in>,
Dr Naveen Kadayinti <naveen@iitdh.ac.in>, Gayathri Ananthanarayanan <
gayathri@iitdh.ac.in>


Dear All,
Mr. Jagabandhu MIshra will give his annual progress seminar (APS) as per
the following:
Title: Spoken language recognition and diariztion
Date: Monday, 15/07/2019, 4.00 PM

All interested are welcome to attend.

Abstract:

*Spoken language recognition* is a task that verifies or identifies the
language spoken in a speech segment. S*poken language diarization* is a
task to automatically segment and label the monolingual segments in a
multilingual speech segment. In this seminar, the need, applications and an
overview of  different methods for spoken language recognition and
diarization are discussed. The x-vector modeling with the multilingual
bottleneck feature (MLBNF) seem to be the state-of-the-art technique for
spoken language recognition. The attempts towards spoken language
diarization seem to be very few, and all the attempts use phonotactic
information and need large transcribed data. The most challenging part of
spoken language diarization is short duration language switching, as most
of the state-of-the-art spoken language recognition systems performance
degrades with decrease in test segment duration. As the spoken language
diarization task is somewhat similar to the speaker diarization task, it is
proposed to discuss the framework of the speaker diarization task. Finally,
motivated from the speaker diarization framework, a spoken language
diarization framework will be proposed for future work.




wbw
Prasanna
--
S. R. Mahadeva Prasanna
Professor, Dept. of Electrical Engineering (on deputation from IITG)
Dean (Faculty Welfare, Research & Development)
Indian Institute of Technology Dharwad
Dharwad - 580011
prasanna@iitdh.ac.in

content.1252:
Subject: Pariksha Pe Charcha 2.0 Contest
Text: Dear All,

The Hon'ble Prime Minister of India will be interacting with students,
teachers, and parents at 11 am on 29th January 2019 on the ways to reduce
exam-related stress, under the Pariksha Pe Charcha 2.0. The physical
interaction with select students will be held in Talkatora Stadium, New
Delhi.

For selecting the students/ teachers/ parents for physical interaction with
the Hon'ble Prime Minister, the contest is being organized for students,
teachers, and parents, on the MyGov India Portal (
https://auth.mygov.in/user/login?destination=oauth2/authorize#mygov_survey_jump).
The selected participants will get an opportunity to meet the Hon'ble Prime
Minister of India at the Talkatora Stadium in New Delhi.

The "Catchy Caption Contest" and "My Success Mantra" Contests are being
organized for students from graduate and undergraduate classes, below 25
years of age. Under the Catchy  Caption Contest, the students will be
required to give a caption, not exceeding 150 characters, for the image
provided in the Pariksha Pe Charcha 2.0 contest. Under the My Success
Mantra Contest, the students can give their inspiring entries for
motivating other exam facing students, in the form of a video (up to 60
seconds duration recorded and link sent on YouTube) or text (up to 500
characters).

 Also, live viewing of the Program is arranged in Room No. 210 on
29th January 2019 at 11 am.

Thanking You.

Regards,
Academic Section

content.1258:
Subject: Hello Android!
Text: Hello everyone,
We are happy to receive such a good response from you. Due to limited
sitting capacity, we would close the registration as soon as it reaches the
threshold so I request the enthusiasts to register fast in case you
haven't.

*Just a few important points for the Hello Android! workshop.*

1. The topics that will be covered are mentioned in the attached document.

2. Create a GitHub account because the repo will be imported from GitHub.

3. In case you are still not able to install Android Studio, fill this form
<https://goo.gl/forms/Cmo42oECdqQQrOB73>. But please try your best before
filling the form <https://goo.gl/forms/MNXS7MDqBglklp223>because you
will encounter such problems often and you have to learn to deal with it. (
That's how you will become a developer)

4. Many of you want to build your own game or app but need some technical
support and advice. So, here is a *Google* initiative *Start on Android*
<https://developer.android.com/google-play/guides/startups> to help early
developers learn to build an app in pre-launch mode, which provides
private, honest feedback from engaged users to help improve apps
performance before releasing them to a broader audience.

5. We have some projects in our mind for the summer but would like to know
your ideas as well, be it hardware, software or a combination. Even if it
is a small project, we would like to know about it.

6. Also, we are happy to see other students coming forward to organize
workshops and we want to develop this culture in our IIT Dharwad. Anyone,
who wants to conduct an event or workshop can directly contact us. We will
provide all sort of support for conducting one in IIT Dharwad.

See you there at the workshop!‚ò∫

Thanks,
OSS Team

content.1261:
Subject: Pan India Engineering Design Contest
Text: Dear Students,

The details of the event is given below.

EngiNx is TCS's Pan India Engineering Design Contest for the Next
Generation, organized annually since 2013.

We are glad to inform that we have launched the seventh edition few weeks
back. In the past six editions of TCS EngiNx we have been seeing
phenomenal innovations that help humanity in leveraging the best in latest
technologies. Many finalists of past editions, have joined us as TCSers,
in the journey of Engineering Innovation!

This year, EngiNx is conceived as "Digital Eminence - Making Things Smart
Challenge"  setting college grads passing in years 2020 and 2021 on the
quest of identifying  use cases and providing engineering solution to a
real world problem, by connecting the ‚ÄòSensors to the Software‚Äô and
enabling efficient decisions through Engineering Algorithms to the end
user.

So far, more than 34,000 students across India have registered for the
contest.

Last date for registration is 25th March 2019
Registration Link: https://on.tcs.com/2NdYGHX
(students can view all details and register for the contest on this link)

As this is a team event, students should form teams and also
enthusiastically participate in Round 1 of the contest (an online round
consisting of Multiple Choice Questions).

Hope to see your teams winning this contest and bringing laurels and pride
to the prestigious institute.

I would also like to share one student's "Journey from EngiNx to EIS" -
this can be viewed at the below link on Campus Commune.

https://campuscommune.tcs.com/channels/eis-engineering-and-industrial-services/blogposts/journey-from-enginx-to-eis-thomas-vimal-easo-k-eng

Important dates of the contest are given below for your quick reference.

Event                                                Start Date
Registration Start                                   15-Feb-19
Close of registrations                               25-Mar-19
MCQ Quiz                                             28-Mar-19
Evaluation and results to be shared (300 teams)      30-Mar-19
Round 1 (Use Case Proposal  Round)                    3-Apr-19
Use case Proposal Submission                         21-Apr-19
Evaluation and results to be shared (150 teams)      24-Apr-19
Round 2 (Video Presentation round)                    7-May-19
Video presentation Submission                         9-Jun-19
Results to be shared (100 teams)                     10-Jun-19
Interactive evaluation with top 50 teams completion  19-Jun-19
Round 3 (Grand Finale Round)                         13-Jul-19
Submission of Presentations                           6-Aug-19
Grand Finale                                          9-Aug-19

Website: http://www.tcs.com

Regards,
Academic Section

Who? Dr. Thirumulanathan

Brief Bio: Thirumulanathan is currently a senior engineer at Qualcomm,
Bengaluru. He received his masters and Ph.D. from the Indian Institute of
Science. His Ph.D. thesis was on designing optimal mechanisms for selling

content.1273:
Subject: Shastri Indo-Canadian Institute - Funding opportunity
Text: FYI ...
Please refer to the attached poster and the respective portal.

*Deadlines: *
Students - 18th Sept. 2019
Faculty - 27th August

FYI ...
====================================
Shastri Indo-Canadian Institute is pleased to announce following programmes
for the year *2019-20 *administered by its offices in India and Canada. The
programmes seeking applications in this round are:


*1.*       *Shastri Institutional Collaborative Research Grant (SICRG)*

*2.*       *Shastri Mobility Programme (SMP)*

*3.*       *Shastri Research Student Fellowship (SRSF)*

*4.*       *Shastri Programme Development Grant (SPDG*)

*5.*       *Shastri Publication Grant (SPG**)*

*6.*       *Shastri Membership Development Grant (SMDG*)

*7.*      *Faculty Development Programme For Vocational Education (FDPVE)*

*8.*       *Shastri Scholar Travel Subsidy Grant (SSTSG)*

*9.*       *SICI Membership Development Fund (SMDF) *
<https://www.shastriinstitute.org/SICI_membership_development_fund_SMDF>



Applications from all domains of studies like Social Sciences and
Humanities, Arts, Commerce & Management and STEM subjects are accepted.
However, applications are encouraged in the focus areas of SICI and priority
areas of MHRD, Govt. of India i.e. Food Security and Sustainable
Development, Energy, Environmental Science and Climate Change, Agricultural
Science & Technology, Health Care Sciences, Nursing, Marine Sciences and
Ocean Studies, Information & Communication Technology, Gaming, Artificial
Intelligence, Sustainable Habitat, Nano-technology Hardware, Water
Resources & River Systems, Advanced Materials, Manufacturing, Security &
Defence, Gender, Bi-lateral Trade and Investment, Securing Future of
Children and Youth, Higher Education, Teacher Education and Training.


In order to give a wider reach to these programmes and benefit the academic
and research community of your institution, we request you to kindly
display the announcement on respective websites and share through various
forums of students and faculty networks of your University/Institution. As
per my understanding, International Research offices dealing with grants
and opportunities-abroad will be ideal to circulate the notification.
However, this may be differently handled at respective institutions. The
poster about programme announcement is attached with email for your
reference and to be used for the notice boards.



*Currently, we are visiting campuses of our member institutions to promote
programmes offered by Shastri Institute. You may let us know the convenient
time to visit your institution/university by the next week so that we can
plan the visit accordingly. *


The details of the programmes are available at our web portal
www.shastriinstitute.org and can be readily accessed through the link:
https://www.shastriinstitute.org/grants-awards-and-opportunities-for-indian-canadian-scholars




In case of any difficulty in submission of applications at Grant Management
System (GMS), scholars can contact at siciapplications@sici.org.in . For
queries related to *programmes namely, SSTSG & SMDF* (Sr. no. 8 & 9),
please write to Ms. Mahmuda Aldeen at  maldeen@ucalgary.ca .
==============================



Thanks,
-
Samarth S. Raut, PhD
Assistant Professor,

Indian Institute of Technology, Dharwad (IIT Dharwad)

International Centre for Theoretical Sciences (ICTS-TIFR), Tata Institute
of Fundamental Research, Bengaluru invites applications from academically
bright and motivated students for the ICTS - S. N. Bhatt Memorial
Excellence Fellowship Program in the summer of 2019. This program offers a
unique opportunity to undergraduate/masters students of Science and
Engineering to work with faculty and post-doctoral fellows of the Centre
and to participate in research at the frontiers of knowledge.

*Eligibility*
Undergraduate students of science, mathematics and engineering, who are in
their third, fourth or fifth year of the program are eligible to apply.
Exceptional undergraduates in their second year may also apply. Masters
degree students and those who have completed their undergraduate are also
welcome to apply.

*How to apply*
Interested candidates should *apply online*
<https://forms.icts.res.in/summer-program/> with their CV and relevant
details. The applicants also need to arrange at least two recommendation
letters. Applications will be normally reviewed around February/March every
year (*deadline for application: *

announcement with potential applicants and request you to display this on

content.1277:
Subject: Annual Progress Seminar of Mr. Sagartanu Pal
Text: Dear all,

The first annual progress seminar of Mr. Sagartanu Pal (PhD student, CSE)
is scheduled to be held on 28th June. Please find the details below. All
interested are welcome.

*Title*: Chromatic Discrepancy and Partial Complementation of Graphs
*Venue*: Room 119
*Time*: 11.30 am to 12.30 pm
*Abstract*:
*In this talk, we discuss problems related to chromatic discrepancy of
graphs and partial complementation of graphs.*




*For a given graph G, let c be a proper vertex coloring. For all induced
subgraphs H of G the absolute difference between the chromatic number œá(H)
and the colors used by c to color H is calculated. The maximum of the
differences is denoted by œÜ_c(G). The chromatic discrepancy, denoted by
œÜ(G), of a graph G is defined to be the minimum œÜ_c(G), over all proper
colorings c of G. If H is restricted to only connected induced subgraphs,
we denote the parameter by œÜÃÇ(G). These parameters, which have potential
applications in channel allocation problems in wireless networks, have been
introduced by Arvind et. al. (Discrete Applied mathematics, 2015). We
survey some results and raise a few open problems on chromatic discrepancy
of graphs.Let H be any induced subgraph of a given Graph G. If we
complement H, the new graph obtained from G is called a partial complement
of G. We ask the question: for a given graph G and a property Œ†, is there a
partial complement of G which satisfies theproperty Œ†? This problem has
been studied recently by Fomin et. al. (SWAT 2018). We obtain that if the
property Œ† is 'cluster' (disjoint union of cliques), then the problem can
be solved in polynomial-time. We also obtain that if the property Œ† is
'H-free' (without any induced copy of H), then there exists a graph which
does not have a partial complement satisfying Œ†. *

Thanks and Regards,
Sandeep

-- 
Sandeep R. B.
Assistant Professor
Computer Science and Engineering
IIT Dharwad

content.1283:
Subject: How to make new habits stick like fevikwik this new year
Text: <https://yourdost.com/?yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhMailer&yd_campaign=GoldenRules&yd_term=19>
<https://yourdost.com/?yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhMailer&yd_campaign=GoldenRules&yd_term=19>

Ah! New Year, a time when most of us ambitiously resolve to take on a new
habit and potentially sustain it for the duration of the year. Habits like
- waking up early, maybe finally hitting the gym, or cooking dinner on our
own etc. *Unfortunately, only 8%  of us manage to stick with these habits.*

But worry not, with the following 3 tips, your habits will have no choice
but to stick like Fevikwik:

*1. 5...4...3...2...1...GO!*

‚ÄúI‚Äôll just spend the first week as my last week of fun, and then start the
Monday after.‚Äù NO! Don‚Äôt do it. Start from day 1. When you feel yourself
hesitate, follow the 5 second rule by Mel Robbins - *Count 5-4-3-2-1 and
MOVE PHYSICALLY*. The window between deciding to take an action and your
mind killing it is 5 seconds. This trick will make sure that you
successfully get through this window and act.

So go get ‚Äòem!

*2. Nano-habits*

A major habit change can seem like a daunting task. But did anyone set in
stone that you need to go all in from day 1? No, not really. So how about
you take baby steps, and then gradually climb your way up?

For eg. You want to wake up earlier. Start with setting your alarm 10 mins
earlier than usual, and then month by month increase this interval. Next,
maybe stop using your phone an hour before going to sleep as phones are
known to affect our sleep cycle. You‚Äôll start noticing the difference very
soon!

Remember, a 1% change (through Nano-Habits) you make each day can result in
a 37 times better you by the end of the year. (1.01^365 = 37.8)

*3. The 2-minute Rule*

A major and natural stumbling block to bringing a change in life is
laziness. For eg. You have decided to hit the gym, but then you wake up and
think about changing into your workout outfit, and laziness takes over like
a heavy weight.

The two minute rule dictates that if you can reduce the time taken to
practice a habit by 2-min, the chances of practicing the same would
increase multi-fold. So, go to sleep in your workout clothes with your
shoes right by your bed.

The reverse applies to the habits you want to cut down on - delay them by
2-minutes. For eg. To reduce binge watching your TV, remove the batteries
from the remote and place them in a different room. This is a very powerful
tool to build on your good habits and cut down on your bad ones.

*It's 2019! This year, let's show your mind who's the boss. Just follow
these rules religiously and there's no looking back*

*Looking for more such tips or motivation? Our Experts are here to help you
stick to your resolution longer -*

connect to an expert now
<https://yourdost.com/chatSession/?workgroup=demo@workgroup.chat.yourdost.com?yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhMailer&yd_campaign=GoldenRules&yd_term=19>

If you face any issues, or have any concerns/queries, please drop us a mail
at campus@yourdost.com


*Standing with You, Team YourDOST*

content.1299:
Subject: Wednesday 10 April, Talk - 1, by Prof. Sengupta on "High Accuracy High-Performance Computing: Present Status and Future Prospects"
Text: Dear all,

All are cordially invited to attend the following talk.

*Title*: High Accuracy High-Performance Computing: Present Status and
Future Prospects.

*Speaker*: Prof. Tapan K. Sengupta
High-Performance Computing (HPC) Laboratory
Department of Aerospace Engineering
Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, INDIA.

*Room No*. 203
*Date: April 10, 2019 (Wednesday)*
*Time:* 2.00 pm - 3.00 pm

*Abstract*:
With enhanced computing power, the importance of high-performance computing
is evident in all fields of science and engineering. In these activities,
the aspects
of higher accuracy of scientific computing need more emphasis. Today direct
numerical simulation (DNS) of canonical flows is possible with
careful computations [1], using dispersion relation preserving (DRP)
schemes [2, 3]. These methods are based on mathematical physics
of wave propagation requiring spatio-temporal analysis of methods and
developing a new branch of studies in computing, the subject of error
dynamics
in computing.

After an introduction of spatio-temporal global spectral analysis of
numerical methods showing the flaws of classical approaches of von Neumann
analysis,
we will focus on examples showcasing the power of this analysis with
applications. Role of numerical group velocity will be shown, in explaining
the existence
of q-waves for convection problems. Existence and creation of polygonal
vortex in shear driven flows will be described emphasizing the role of
mathematical physics of this class of problems. Some issues related to
obtaining an equilibrium flow for mixed convection problem will be
described. The solution of the classical, unsolved turbulence problem of
physics (as stated by Feynman) will be highlighted [4, 5]. Finally, we will
discuss issues of high performance related issues of scientific computing.


*References:*

[1] High Accuracy Computing Methods: Fluid Flows and Wave Phenomenon ‚Äì
Tapan K. Sengupta, Cambridge Univ. Press, New York, USA (2013)

[2] IUTAM Symposium Proceedings: "Advances in Computation, Modeling and
Control of Transitional and Turbulent Flows." (Eds.: T. K. Sengupta, S. K.
Lele, K. R. Sreenivasan and P. A. Davidson) World Sci. Pub. Co., Singapore
(2015) See also: Different routes of transition by spatio-temporal
wave-front‚ÄìBhaumik, S., Sengupta, T.K. and Mudkavi, V. Y.; In this
proceeding on pages 68-83.

[3] Space-time discretizing optimal DRP schemes for flow and wave
propagation Problems - T. K. Sengupta, M. K. Rajpoot and Y. G. Bhumkar,
Comput. Fluids, 47(1), 144-154 (2011)

[4] "DNS of Wall-Bounded Turbulent Flows: A First Principle Approach."
Tapan K. Sengupta and S. Bhaumik, Springer Nature, Singapore (2019)

[5] Three-dimensional transition of zero-pressure-gradient boundary layer
by impulsively and non-impulsively started harmonic wall excitation - P.
Sharma, T. K. Sengupta, and S. Bhaumik, Physical Review E, 98, 053106
(2018); See also: Impulse response and spatio-temporal wave-packets: The
common feature of rogue waves, tsunami and transition to turbulence - S.
Bhaumik, T.K. Sengupta, Physics of Fluids, vol. 29, pp 124103 (2017)

*Speaker Bio:*
Prof. T.K. Sengupta is a renowned scientist in the field of computational
fluid dynamics (CFD) and high-performance computing (HPC). His
comprehensive CV is attached for your reference.

*Participation in large numbers is highly encouraged.*

Thank you,
Sincerely,
Dhiraj.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Dr. Dhiraj V. Patil
Assistant Professor (Homepage
<https://sites.google.com/site/dvpmultiplefluidsatiitmandi/>)
Department of Mechanical Engineering,
Indian Institute of Technology Dharwad.

content.1304:
Subject: Talk on MEMS accelerometers using suspended gate CMOS transistors
Text: Dear Colleagues and students,

We will have a seminar on "MEMS accelerometers using suspended gate
transistors" by
Ms. Anju Sebastian. The details of the talk, abstract and bio are as follows

Title : "MEMS accelerometers using suspended gate transistors"
Date and Time : 2 PM 3 PM on Friday, 15th March
Speaker : Anju Sebastian (M.Tech student at IIST Trivandrum)
Venue: Rm No. 119

Abstract: MEMS (Micro-Electro Mechanical Systems) accelerometers have
several advantages like small size, low power consumption, robust sensing
and convenient cost. MEMS accelerometers are widely used in various motion
sensing applications including medical, industrial, and military where
measurement of acceleration, vibration, etc is required. Most of these
sensors depend on capacitive sensing techniques for monitoring the
displacement of moving elements. In this work, we introduce a novel sensing
scheme utilizing a laterally movable gate field effect transistor (LMGFET).
Lateral motion of the FET gate results in a change in channel width. This
results in a change in channel current that, in principle, is linearly
proportional to mechanical motion/ acceleration. The device can be used to
detect milli-g range of acceleration. The sensor has high sensitivity, low
cross-axis sensitivity and excellent linearity. The challenges in design,
implementation and simulation of the LMGFET accelerometer will be discussed.
--
Regards,
Naveen Kadayinti
content.1305:
Subject: I Was Scared of Counseling.
Text: Dear Students,

Hope you are making the most of the summer break- whether at internship, or
at home, or at learning what you wanted to learn.

*Sharing with you a first-hand account of a former student on grades,
pressure and stress. *

This is to encourage those of you facing a bumpy ride to seek a helping
hand.
And to never lose to stress.


Best Wishes,
Ridhima



> YourDOST
>
> <https://yourdost.com/?yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhEmail&yd_campaign=ScaredCase&yd_term=19>
>
> <https://yourdost.com/?yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhEmail&yd_campaign=ScaredCase&yd_term=19>
> Dec. 2015, I remember when I first heard the words, ‚Äúyou have brought
> shame to the family‚Äù. Let me explain. I had joined my college about 5
> months back. My parents expected me to be studious and get placed into a
> top company with ideally a 7 figure salary. So, I would study hard, even at
> the cost of being made fun of and bullied. But I also made sure that I
> socialised, made friends, and pursued a sport.
> A semester went by. I was at home for the sem break when my exam results
> were announced. I had scored a 8.75 GPA. It was decent, or so I thought.
> Then my parents saw it and suddenly it felt like someone had died in the
> house.‚ÄúYou have brought shame to the family‚Äù, my dad said. My heart sank. I
> was in the top 20 of my class, and here I was being treated like a failure
> by my own parents.
> For the next 1 year, my parents would check up on me at least 5 times in a
> day. If I didn‚Äôt answer my phone, they'd call my roommate. If I was out
> with friends, I would get yelled at for throwing away my life. I wasn‚Äôt
> allowed to have fun anymore. I slipped into depression, skipping classes,
> meals, and even socialising. My self-confidence and self-esteem hit
> rock-bottom. I had no idea what to do, and had to finally consider the idea
> of counseling.
> But I wasn‚Äôt ready to meet with a counselor in person. That‚Äôs when I came
> across a poster on my campus about an online counseling portal. I decided
> to give it a shot. I got onto the portal, and was connected with Ruchi.
> Will she judge me?‚Äù, ‚ÄúHow can she ever help me?‚Äù, ‚ÄúThis is a bad idea‚Äù,
> were some of the thoughts running in my head. But Ruchi made me feel so
> comfortable. I can tell you that with her, I got exactly what I needed,
> compassion, empathy, guidance and a patient ear, without even a tinge of
> judgement.
> As I got more comfortable with her, I took her suggestion and we moved to
> sessions over Skype. At her request, I asked my parents to speak with her.
> At first, they were angry. ‚ÄúWhy do you need counseling?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat mistakes did
> we ever make to see this day?‚Äù, they said. But on my repeated pleadings,
> they gave in. The change in their behaviour was miraculous. It was like I
> had lost my parents and had now found them again. 3 months later, I emerged
> from counseling with renewed vigour, confidence, and self-worth. Most
> importantly, I felt hope - hope that I could be happy again.
> In July 2018, I joined my first job in one of the world‚Äôs foremost
> consultancy firms with a 7 figure salary. In the end, I just have one thing
> to say, neither is counseling something to be scared of, nor is it
> something to be ashamed of.
> Got something on your mind that‚Äôs troubling you? We‚Äôre here for you.
>
> connect with an expert now
> <https://yourdost.com/chatSession/?workgroup=demo@workgroup.chat.yourdost.com&yd_source=IITDh_NL&yd_medium=IITDhEmail&yd_campaign=ScaredCase&yd_term=19>
>
> YourDOST
>


-- 



Ridhima Tewari

content.1309:
Subject: Fwd: Six ‚Äì week Summer Internship on ‚ÄúCAD/CAM & Industrial Automation using various commercial software packages‚Äù during June 1 ‚Äì July 15, 2019
Text: ---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: *Dr Rajeev Verma* <vermar@nitj.ac.in>
Date: Tuesday, May 14, 2019
Subject: Six ‚Äì week Summer Internship on ‚ÄúCAD/CAM & Industrial Automation
using various commercial software packages‚Äù during June 1 ‚Äì July 15, 2019
To: Rajeev verma <rajeev.pec123@gmail.com>



Dear Sir/Madam,

Greetings from NIT Jalandhar!

It is our pleasure to inform you that the Department of Industrial &
Production Engineering, NIT Jalandhar is organizing a self-sponsored Six ‚Äì
week Summer Internship on ‚ÄúCAD/CAM & Industrial Automation using various
commercial software packages‚Äù during June 1 ‚Äì July 15, 2019.

The objective of the course is to train participants to carry out projects
based on mechanical drawing and design using the CAD / CAM & CAE software
tools. The training is aimed to achieved the following objectives:

√ò  Introduction to Engineering Drawing, Mechanical Drawing, Methods of
Projection, Isometric and Orthographic Projections, Introduction to machine
drawing and assemblies.

√ò  Introduction to Finite Element Method: Basic Steps of FEM, FEM Modelling
and applications of FEM to 1D Problems in Solid Mechanics, Fluid Mechanics
and Heat Transfer Problems.

√ò  Hands-on practice on 3-D Modelling, Simulation and Analysis packages,
such as AutoCAD, Creo Parametric 4.0, and Fusion 360.

√ò  Hands-on practice on automation and simulation packages such as
Automation Studio and MATLAB.

√ò  Hands-on practice on Production Simulation using Flex-Sim / Pro-Model



The program will comprise of lectures, demonstration sessions properly
blended with practical hands-on on the relevant modelling, simulation and
analysis tools - AutoCAD, Creo Parametric 4.0, Fusion 360, Automation
Studio, MATLAB, Flex-Sim / Pro-Model.



Please find enclosed .pdf copy of the workshop flyer. I kindly request you
to participate in this workshop and to share our invitation among your
colleagues, students & scholars. The participation is open to B-Tech,
M-Tech. and PhD students, Post-docs, faculty, and Industry personnel.
Please note that we can accommodate limited number of participants.

-- 

*Thanks & Regards.*

*Rajeev Verma, PhD*
*Assistant Professor*
*Department of Industrial & Production Engineering*
*Dr B R Ambedkar National Institute of Technology,*
*GT Road Amritsar Bypass, **Jalandhar, Punjab, INDIA -144011*

*Tel: 0181-2690-301-02, Extn. 2852 (O)*
*Mob. +91-9464740847*
*vermar@nitj.ac.in <vermar@nitj.ac.in>, **rajeev.pec123@gmail.com
<rajeev.pec123@gmail.com>*
Institute web site: https://nitj.ac.in

--

Subject: 2019 Commonwealth Scholarship in the UK: Corrigendum in respect of public notice dated 23.10.2018-regarding.
Text: Dear All,

It is reiterated that the following scholarships are being offered by the
Commonwealth Scholarship Commission, UK to Indian students, starting from
September/October 2019 and tenable in the UK:



            *i) Commonwealth Master‚Äôs Scholarships (for low and middle
income Commonwealth countries) *

*            ii) Commonwealth PhD Scholarships (for low and middle income
Commonwealth countries)*



The Ministry of Human Resource Development is the nodal agency for
nomination of the Indian students under the aforesaid scholarship. The
online applications are being invited under the aforesaid scholarship.
Applicants are required to apply online at the following portals:



*Ministry of Human Resource Development portal by 17th January, 2019.*



Link for online application: http://proposal.sakshat.ac.in/scholarship/



*Commonwealth Scholarship Commission‚Äôs Electronic Application System (EAS)
by 19.12.2018 by 16:00 (GMT)*

Link for EAS: https://fs29.formsite.com/m3nCYq/form62/form_login.html



*(Both applications are mandatory)*



The detailed information of the scholarship is available in the Public
Notice which has already been displayed on the website of the Ministry of
Human Resource Development i.e. www.mhrd.gov.in/scholarships .

Regards,

*Academic Section*

content.1319:
Subject: Fwd: (ML + AI) workshop by Alphazeo team, Techniche, IIT Guwahati
Text: ---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: SONU SOURAV <170020021@iitdh.ac.in>
Date: Tue, Jul 24, 2018 at 11:55 AM
Subject: (ML + AI) workshop by Alphazeo team, Techniche, IIT Guwahati
To: MD RIZWAN ANSARI <160010015@iitdh.ac.in>, SONU SOURAV <
170020021@iitdh.ac.in>


Hello everyone!
Hope everybody enjoyed your holidays .
Many of you might have come across jargons like ML and AI but often ignored
it because you never knew how to play around with it.Well then, you will be
glad to know that a team from IIT Guwahati is looking to conduct a 2 days
workshop in IIT Dharwad on Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence,
followed by zonal level competition.
     * Alphazeo Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence Championship
2018* is a challenge and workshop series jointly being organized by *Techniche
2018, IIT Guwahati* and *Verzeo*.There will be two rounds:

1.* Zonal Round *in zonal colleges

2. *Final round* in IIT Guwahati

For zonal round, there are two modes:
(a) Offline :  2 days (7 hrs/ day) hands on workshop will be conducted on
(ML + AI) course only.
(b) Online : Those who won't be able to attend workshop, they can access
online material either for 15 days or 45 days (based on convenience). For
online, in addition to above
                 course you  can choose other courses like* Microsoft Azure
Cloud Computing , Cyber security , Web development *and *Robotics* as well.

Registration and other details are mentioned in the attachment below. The
date and venue to be decided later.

Right now we want the headcount of interested students.If its above margin
limit , we will go further.Interested students fill the google form shared
with you.

Google form <https://goo.gl/forms/TUejiH6SRDVZL9qp1>

For any queries, you can contact either persons below mentioned.

MD RIZWAN ANSARI
160010015@iitdh.ac.in

Sonu Sourav
Mob No: 9916228725


Thanks,

*MD RIZWAN ANSARI*
theCodingClub Secretary
IIT DHARWAD.

content.1325:
Subject: Auditions for play on Teacher's Day
Text: Dear all,

For selecting actors for the play on Teacher's Day which is on 5th of
September, we are conducting auditions for the roles. The audition will be
conducted in two slots:

1) Academic Building, Room 22: *10.15 *to *11.15* am
2) Bhoopali Building, Board Games Room: *11.30* am to *12.30 *pm

We recommend to bring your own script for the auditions. It should be
around 1 to 2 minutes long. If not possible, we will try to provide you
with a script. Also, duo auditions are allowed.

The panel for the audition will consist of the following council members:

1) Gourav Kumbhojkar (Council Member Direction)
2) Vibhuti Raman (Council Member Acting)
3) Amogh Dasture

Regards,
Amogh Dasture,
Dramatics Club Secretary.

P.S: I am happy to announce that we have got an official name for the club.
The name is 'Udghosh'.

content.1338:
Subject: QF1 League
Text: For the past 2 years, Quiz Foundation of India (QFI) has been running a
format called the QF1 at their fortnightly meetings. It is a light prelims
style set of 30 general questions that participants attempt *lonewolf*.
Every other week, they send out the question set to interested quiz centres
across the globe.
For more FAQs, visit here.
<http://www.quizfoundation.com/2018/08/16/qf1-league-faqs/>

We plan to incorporate this at our campus too. This would be a great
opportunity to compare yourselves against the best in the world.

The first set will be conducted tomorrow, i.e. *11-11-2018* in *Room no 22*
from *9 PM*.
Interested participants should report with a pen. The scores would be
tabulated every week and you can check your progress here
<https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1P9soxRyS4OzDwksw9b2QM0_RMjUcdoFB1cd597CEUzM/edit#gid=0>
.

If you have any doubts, contact me.


Thanks,
Shivam Chaturvedi
180010032
content.1339:
Subject: Fwd: Solar Decathlon - Middle East Dubai, UAE 2020
Text: ---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Consul (Education) <edu.dubai@mea.gov.in>
Date: Mon, Jul 23, 2018 at 4:23 PM
Subject: Fwd: Solar Decathlon - Middle East Dubai, UAE 2020
To: director@iitkgp.ac.in


Dear Madam/Sir,

Greetings from the Consulate General of India, Dubai.

Please refer to the trail mail and the attachments.

Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA), is Dubai Government's agency
responsible for making available to the people of Dubai an adequate and
reliable supply of electricity and water. DEWA is organising Solar
Decathlon Middle East (SDME) which consist of 10 contests that challenge
students to design and build solar-powered houses.

We hope that SDME will give an opportunity to the students of your esteemed
institute to showcase their talent and creativity.

You are requested to bring the information about the SDME to notice of the
concerned department and students of your esteemed institute so that they
can participate in SDME.

Details about SDME can be obtained from the website:
www.solardecathlonme.com or by sending e mail to sdme2020@dewa.gov.ae


Thanks and regards,

Pankaj Bodkhe
Consul(Education)
Consulate General of India, Dubai.




-------- Original Message --------
From: *cgoffice *<cgoffice.dubai@mea.gov.in>
Date: Jul 23, 2018 9:53:20 AM
Subject: FW: Solar Decathlon - Middle East Dubai, UAE 2020
To: consuleconomic@mea.gov.in, edu.dubai@mea.gov.in





*From:* SDME2020 [mailto:sdme2020@dewa.gov.ae]
*Sent:* Wednesday, July 18, 2018 11:08 AM
*To:* cgoffice.dubai@mea.gov.in
*Cc:* Bernadette Braganza
*Subject:* Solar Decathlon - Middle East Dubai, UAE 2020



Your Excellency, Mr. Vipul



Warm greetings from Dubai Electricity and Water Authority! I hope you are
well.We would like to take this chance to introduce our International
initiative aiming at engaging academic institutions in further energy
efficiency research.



The Solar Decathalon Middle East (SDME) competition is a partnership
between the Supreme Council of Energy and DEWA, with the US Department of
Energy. Dubai will host the first two rounds of the Solar Decathalon, in
November 2018 and in 2020. Participating university teams will design,
build and operate sustainable and cost and energy ‚Äì efficient models of
solar powered homes, with a focus on protecting the environment and taking
into consideration the climatic conditions of the region.



While the plans are underway for the competition this year in 2018, we
would like to seek your help in introducing us to Universities that would
like to be a part of the same in 2020 as we begin our outreach program. We
will be accepting Expression of Interest (EOI) via our online site
(www.solardecathalonme.com) <http://www.solardecathalonme.com/> until the
end of November.



Please let us know if you have any further enquiries and we look forward to
your engagement in the competition. Kindly find attached the SDME poster
and competition leaflets for the same.



We look forward to a positive response from your end. Have a lovely day.

Warm regards,

*SDME TEAM*

P.O.Box: 564 Dubai ‚Äì UAE   Phone: 04-3223009

SDME2020@dewa.gov.ae   ‚Ä¢  www.dewa.gov.ae

Subject: Fwd: Lybrate Grow India Scholarship - a chance to secure the future of your child!
Text: ---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Pratyush Choudhury <pratyush.choudhury@lybrate.com>
Date: Thu, 24 May 2018 at 5:24 PM
Subject: Lybrate Grow India Scholarship - a chance to secure the future of
your child!
To:






*Respected Sir/Madam, Lybrate takes the opportunity to humbly inform you
about the maiden Lybrate Grow India Scholarship, a unique opportunity for
parents to secure the health and education of their children with a yearly
amount of Rs 50,000/- for the next 15 years. We need your support to widely
disseminate the information about the scholarship among your circle. A
small effort will go a long way in securing a child's future.    Lybrate is
India's first and largest mobile healthcare communication and delivery
platform. As a healthcare company, we understand that a healthy mind
resides in a healthy body. We are also aware that poor health adversely
affects the education of children. So to ensure the best for a child's
future, we have decided to combine the two.  The Scholarship is a
merit-cum-means scholarship, which aims to create a better future for
children through twin goals - Good Health and Good Education. Lybrate will
provide 10 scholarships to children from across the country. *

*Key features of the scholarship:-*

   - *Free education:- Your child will be provided with an assistance Rs
   25,000/- every year towards education. *
   -

* Free healthcare:- Your child will be provided with an assistance of Rs
   25,000/- every year towards healthcare. *
   -

* To apply - Click Here!
   <https://get.lybrate.com/grow-india/?utm_source=college&utm_medium=mails&utm_campaign=GrowIndiaScholarship>*
   -

* To know more about Lybrate, you can visit us at - www.lybrate.com
   <http://www.lybrate.com>*

*Who can apply:-*

   - The registration is *FREE*
   - All *adult individuals*, having *a child/children* aged between *0-19
   years*, are eligible to participate.
   - In fact, even expecting mothers are encouraged to apply.
   - The applicants must be Indian Nationals.




*Application deadline is July 15, 2018.Kindly spread the information about
this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity among your staff, faculty and student
community through your internal communication channels. It will be
Lybrate's pleasure to take forward this noble initiative together.

content.1355:
Subject: Re: Talk by Dr. S. Vanka at 1400 in Rm no. 119
Text: Dear colleagues and students,

A gentle reminder for the talk today. The venue will be room number 119.

Regards,
Naveen

On Mon, 8 Oct, 2018, 17:39 Naveen Kadayinti, <naveen@iitdh.ac.in> wrote:

>
> Dear Colleagues and Students
>
> We have a visitor, Dr. Sundaram Vanka, to the institute on 11th October.
> He will be giving a talk on 11th October from 1400 to 1500 Hrs. The details
> of the talk are as follows.
>
> Title : Interference Management in Emerging Wireless Networks and Systems
>
> Abstract: An important source of complexity in emerging wireless networks
> is the increasingly diverse set of wireless devices and their applications.
> Interference management is a key challenge in the design and operation of
> such networks, and forms the overall theme that connects the speaker‚Äôs work
> in diverse settings. This talk provides a brief overview of some aspects of
> this work and is organized as follows. Part one situates his work in the
> overall context of interference management and provides a bird‚Äôs eye view
> of his work both in academia and in industry. Parts two and three will
> discuss selected topics from his work in industry and as an academic
> researcher, respectively. The talk concludes with some thoughts on the
> challenges posed by the increased device heterogeneity expected in future
> wireless networks.
>
> The talk will touch upon the speaker‚Äôs contributions to three challenging
> problems in wireless LAN (WLAN, commonly called ‚ÄúWi-Fi‚Äù) system design that
> form some of the core technology in flagship wireless LAN SoC products. The
> first two topics pertain to some of his work at  Broadcom on the general
> problem of wireless coexistence, where devices with very different
> communication requirements and constraints share a common spectrum. The
> roles of interference avoidance, mitigation and adaptation are discussed in
> the context of specific examples. It is pointed out how a holistic
> perspective on the system-level impact of interference is necessary for
> significantly improved coexistence. The third topic is selected to present
> some of his work at Redpine Signals, Inc., that concerns the design of
> low-complexity soft-output MIMO demodulators. It is shown how reasonably
> accurate Likelihood-Ratios (LLRs) can be obtained without the need for
> matrix inversion when the number of spatial streams is small, a scenario of
> practical interest.
>
> As part of his doctoral research, the speaker has worked on multiple
> theoretical and experimental topics. One representative topic from each
> methodology will be presented here. The experimental work will discuss the
> development of the first known prototype of a superposition coded wireless
> system that was implemented on a software radio platform. In addition to
> systematically developing experimentally robust analogs and methodologies
> to theoretical constructs (such as the information-theoretic rate region),
> this line of work also investigates some approaches that can leverage
> superposition coding in practice. The theoretical topic will discuss his
> work on deriving asymptotic scaling laws for the convergence behavior for a
> class of distributed signal processing algorithms called average consensus
> algorithms when message exchange between network nodes occurs over an
> interference-limited wireless network. By combining the mathematical tools
> from Markov chain theory, geometric random graph theory and information
> theory, this line of work was the first to establish convergence results on
> this algorithm in the presence of interference. In particular, it
> challenges the long-held view that increased communication range always
> improves the rate of convergence to consensus.
>
> The talk ends with some thoughts on the emergence of device heterogeneity,
> and some challenges this poses in the context of the emerging Internet of
> Things (IoT).
>
> Speaker bio: Sundaram Vanka received the B. Tech. and M. Tech. degrees
> from the Indian Institute of Technology, Madras in 2003, and the Ph. D.
> degree from the University of Notre Dame, Indiana, United States of America
> in 2012, all in Electrical Engineering. Since 2012 he has been with the
> wireless LAN (WLAN) systems architecture group at Broadcom Inc., a
> market-leading designer, developer and supplier of WLAN chips on diverse
> platforms, where he is currently Principal R&D engineer in the systems
> architecture group. He leads systems R&D efforts into new system
> architectures and protocols for interference management and coexistences
> protocols, and defines the technology roadmap for these technologies. His
> expertise and charter spans the mathematical modeling, design,
> implementation, laboratory characterization and productization of
> OFDM-based system design, interference-mitigation and coexistence protocols
> for multiband/multichannel Wi-Fi and Wi-Fi/Bluetooth combo solutions. His
> designs form a critical part of Broadcom‚Äôs flagship WLAN/Bluetooth combo
> System-on-Chip (SoC) products that are shipped to leading consumer
> electronics companies. His work has resulted in 15 US patents (7 granted, 8
> pending).
>
> His research interests lie in wireless communications and networking,
> spanning the mathematical modeling, simulation, design and prototyping of
> wireless systems and networks. He believes the coming Internet of Things
> opens up the possibility of re-evaluating some traditional assumptions
> about wireless networks and offer new interesting topics for theoretical
> and as well as experimental investigation.
>
> --
> Regards,
> Naveen
>

content.1362:
Subject: Young Leaders' Initiative Summer Camp
Text: Hey there everyone
So half the semester is done and there's just 2 months for the vacations!
Most of you would've plans for your vacations like playing a sport,
learning something new,
travelling or just sitting in your house and royally wasting time (my
all-time favourite :P)
Since we're getting about 75 days of holidays, you can surely do all of
that, maybe have some time left too. So in that left over/leisure time, why
don't you consider doing something fun and actually useful for the society?

Young Leaders' Initiative is a program where you can teach what you love to
the students of rural areas, who have lesser opportunities than us.
So the program is just for 15 days (that's a decent amount of time, but
still) and you'll have to stay in a rural area, teaching kids (7th to 12th
class) what you opt for.

Try giving it a thought, I know all seems quite a little of a drag, but
then you'll be learning a lot, making new friends and doing good for the
children.

Now, for the rewards part(All we care about us this xD). You get around
5000/- to 7000/- upon completion for the program, depending on your
proficiency.

For the TL;DR people, basically this is a social cause which allows you to
teach children from the lower backrounds what you love and you get paid for
doing so.

Where, when and all can be found here
http://www.youngleadersinitiative.com

P.S. Don't think language is a problem, there are students from 15 other
countries participating

>
>> Dear all,
>>
>> There is a talk by Dr. Unnikrishnan C (Research Fellow, SUTD, Singapore)
>> on this Wednesday (20th March) from 2.30 pm to 3.30 pm. Please find the
>> details below. All interested are welcome.
>>
>> *Title*: Compilation for distributed systems
>> *Venue*: Room 23
>> *Time*: 2.30 pm to 3.30 pm
>> *Speaker*: Dr. Unnikrishnan C
>> *Abstract*: Graphs model relationships across real-world entities in web
>> graphs, social network graphs, and road network graphs. Graph algorithms
>> are irregular, i.e memory access patterns varies with each graph object.
>> Graph algorithms analyze and transform a graph object to discover graph
>> properties or to apply a computation. For instance a community detection
>> algorithm discovers likely communities in a social network. In Domains such
>> as social information systems, the number of edges can be in billions or
>> trillions.
>>
>> Graph algorithms can be executed on multi-core CPUs, GPUs with thousands
>> of cores, multi-GPU devices, and CPU+GPU clusters, depending on the size of
>> the graph object. Inorder to program such algorithms on heterogeneous
>> targets, a programmer is required to deal with parallelism and also manage
>> explicit data communication between distributed devices. This implies that
>> a programmer is required to learn CUDA, OpenMP, MPI, etc. and also the
>> details of the hardware architecture. Such codes are error prone and
>> difficult to debug.
>>
>> The talk will focus on,  Falcon, a graph Domain Specific Language ( DSL)
>> for data analytics on graph, and its compiler. The compiler is developed as
>> part of the PhD work of Dr.Unnikrishnan C. Falcon programs are explicitly
>> parallel and Falcon hides all the hardware and communication details from a
>> programmer. Falcon support distributed systems with CPU and GPU. Another
>> feature of Falcon is that it supports mutation of graph objects and thus
>> enables programming dynamic graph algorithms. In Falcon  a programmer needs
>> to focus only on the algorithmic logic, making it easy to program and hence
>> increase productivity.
>>
>> *Short Bio: *Dr. Unnikrishnan C is a Research Fellow at Singapore
>> University of Technology and Design (SUTD), Singapore. He obtained PhD from
>> IISc in 2018. He has a teaching experience of around five years. His
>> interests are in Compilers and Programming Languages.
>>
>> Thanks and Regards,
>> Sandeep

>> Computer Science and Engineering
>> IIT Dharwad

content.1367:
Subject: Talk by Dr. Unnikrishnan on 20th March (Wednesday) 2.30 pm
Text: Dear all,

There is a talk by Dr. Unnikrishnan C (Research Fellow, SUTD, Singapore) on
this Wednesday (20th March) from 2.30 pm to 3.30 pm. Please find the
details below. All interested are welcome.

*Title*: Compilation for distributed systems
*Venue*: Room 23
*Time*: 2.30 pm to 3.30 pm
*Speaker*: Dr. Unnikrishnan C
*Abstract*: Graphs model relationships across real-world entities in web
graphs, social network graphs, and road network graphs. Graph algorithms
are irregular, i.e memory access patterns varies with each graph object.
Graph algorithms analyze and transform a graph object to discover graph
properties or to apply a computation. For instance a community detection
algorithm discovers likely communities in a social network. In Domains such
as social information systems, the number of edges can be in billions or
trillions.

Graph algorithms can be executed on multi-core CPUs, GPUs with thousands of
cores, multi-GPU devices, and CPU+GPU clusters, depending on the size of
the graph object. Inorder to program such algorithms on heterogeneous
targets, a programmer is required to deal with parallelism and also manage
explicit data communication between distributed devices. This implies that
a programmer is required to learn CUDA, OpenMP, MPI, etc. and also the
details of the hardware architecture. Such codes are error prone and
difficult to debug.

The talk will focus on,  Falcon, a graph Domain Specific Language ( DSL)
for data analytics on graph, and its compiler. The compiler is developed as
part of the PhD work of Dr.Unnikrishnan C. Falcon programs are explicitly
parallel and Falcon hides all the hardware and communication details from a
programmer. Falcon support distributed systems with CPU and GPU. Another
feature of Falcon is that it supports mutation of graph objects and thus
enables programming dynamic graph algorithms. In Falcon  a programmer needs
to focus only on the algorithmic logic, making it easy to program and hence
increase productivity.

*Short Bio: *Dr. Unnikrishnan C is a Research Fellow at Singapore
University of Technology and Design (SUTD), Singapore. He obtained PhD from
IISc in 2018. He has a teaching experience of around five years. His
interests are in Compilers and Programming Languages.

Thanks and Regards,
Sandeep

-- 
Sandeep R. B.
Assistant Professor
Computer Science and Engineering
IIT Dharwad
